Screen.title: TopScreen
Screen.Label: ---------- Mouse Button 1 click on field to change ----------

Help.Tip: Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
Help.Text:
kmig - PROCESSDEFAULTS
Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
 
 Default = SYSTEM
 Allowed = SYSTEM
 Allowed = PROJECT
 Allowed = USER
 SYSTEM defaults are the defaults listed in the CPS documentation.
 
 PROJECT defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as Project
 Default button.
 
 USER defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as User Default
 button.

Help.Tip: Press button to display memory and disk usage.
Help.Text:
kmig - DISPLAY_INFO
Press button to display memory and disk usage.
 
 When the DISPLAY_INFO button is pressed the memory and disk
 requirements are computed and displayed.
 This will enforce default value settings.

Help.Tip: The dimensionality of the migration and data.
Help.Text:
kmig - DIMENSION
The dimensionality of the migration and data.
 
 Default = 2D
 Allowed = 2D means 2D time or depth migration all y values assumed to be 0..
 Allowed = 3D means 3D time or depth migration.
 Allowed = M2D means 2D time or depth migration with multiple y values.

Help.Tip: X header word.
Help.Text:
kmig - HDR_X
X header word.
 
 Default = 7
 Allowed = 7,8,17,18

Help.Tip: Type of imaging.
Help.Text:
kmig - MIG_TYPE
Type of imaging.
 
 Default = TIM_MIG
 Allowed = TIM_MIG - Time migration.
 Allowed = DEP_MIG - Depth migration.
 Allowed = DMO     - DMO

Help.Tip: Vertical output coordinate scale factor for depth migration.
Help.Text:
kmig - DEP_SCALE
Vertical output coordinate scale factor for depth migration.
 
 Default = 1000.
 Allowed = real > 0
 DEP_SCALE is not used for time migration and DMO.
 Scale factor to scale output sample rate and start time to pseudo time units.
 For depth migration The output sample rate and minimum time are scaled by
 SAMPLE RATE = TIM_INIT / DEP_SCALE
 START TIME  = TIM_INIT / DEP_SCALE

Help.Tip: Type of input and output order.
Help.Text:
kmig - SORT_ORDER
Type of input and output order.
 
 Default = X_IS_FAST
 Allowed = X_IS_FAST the fastest changing header word is HDR_X,
 the second fastest changing header word is HDR_Y
 and the slowest changing header word is the offset header word.
 Allowed = Y_IS_FAST the fastest changing header word is HDR_Y,
 the second fastest changing header word is HDR_X
 and the slowest changing header word is the offset header word.

Help.Tip: Y header word.
Help.Text:
kmig - HDR_Y
Y header word.
 
 Default = 8
 Allowed = 7,8,17,18

Help.Tip: Imaging direction.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_DIR
Imaging direction.
 
 Default = FORWARD
 Allowed = FORWARD migration normal migration.
 Allowed = INVERSE migration, modeling, not used for depth migration.

Help.Tip: Remove the image files when the job is completed.
Help.Text:
kmig - REMOVE_IMAGE
Remove the image files when the job is completed.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES KMIG will remove the image files at the end of the job.
 Allowed = NO  KMIG will not remove the image files.

Help.Tip: Recover the image files from a fialed job.
Help.Text:
kmig - RECOVER_IMAGE
Recover the image files from a fialed job.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES KMIG will recover the image files from a failed job.
 Allowed = NO  KMIG will operate as normal.

Help.Tip: Root name of image file names.
Help.Text:
kmig - ROOT_IMAGE
Root name of image file names.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character
 KMIG places each pe image traces in a separate temprorary disk file.
 If ROOT_IMAGE is defined KMIG will construct the image file
 with the prefix ROOT_IMAGE.

Help.Tip: Stack the output traces.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_STACK
Stack the output traces.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES
 Allowed = NO
 If OPT_STACK=YES  KMIG will     stack the output traces from all pes.
 If OPT_STACK=NO   KMIG will not stack the output traces from all pes.
 If OPT_STACK=NO and OPT_TROT=LAST
 KMIG will write the image traces from each pe to a separate FILE
 whose name will be defined by ROOT_TROT with the pe index and '.trc' apended.
 KMIG will also write a list of those file names and the number of
 traces written to the file to an ascii file.
 whose name will be defined by ROOT_TROT with '.list' apended.

Help.Tip: Write output to trot file every NUM_TROT traces.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_TROT
Write output to trot file every NUM_TROT traces.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES
 Allowed = NO
 Allowed = LAST
 If OPT_TROT=YES  KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces.
 If OPT_TROT=NO   KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 If OPT_TROT=LAST KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces and after the last input trace.
 KMIG will print a banner starting with kmig_trot starting the number
 of input traces contained in the image at output time.
 Header word HDR_FOLD is set to the number of input traces in the image.

Help.Tip: Write output to trot file every NUM_TROT traces.
Help.Text:
kmig - NUM_TROT
Write output to trot file every NUM_TROT traces.
 
 Default = 999999
 Allowed = INT>0
 If OPT_TROT=YES  KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces.
 If OPT_TROT=NO   KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 If OPT_TROT=LAST KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces and after the last input trace.
 KMIG will print a banner starting with kmig_trot starting the number
 of input traces contained in the image at output time.
 Header word HDR_FOLD is set to the number of input traces in the image.

Help.Tip: Select file name.
Help.Text:
kmig - SELECT_ROOT_TROT
Select file name.
 
 If OPT_TROT=YES  KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces.
 If OPT_TROT=NO   KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 If OPT_TROT=LAST KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces and after the last input trace.
 KMIG will print a banner starting with kmig_trot starting the number
 of input traces contained in the image at output time.
 Header word HDR_FOLD is set to the number of input traces in the image.

Help.Tip: Output file name.
Help.Text:
kmig - ROOT_TROT
Output file name.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character
 If OPT_TROT=YES  KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces.
 If OPT_TROT=NO   KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 If OPT_TROT=LAST KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces and after the last input trace.
 KMIG will print a banner starting with kmig_trot starting the number
 of input traces contained in the image at output time.
 Header word HDR_FOLD is set to the number of input traces in the image.

Help.Tip: Number of image time points to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - TIM_TOT
Number of image time points to migrate data to.
 
 Default = NDPT
 Allowed = int > 0

Help.Tip: Number of image depth points to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - DEP_TOT
Number of image depth points to migrate data to.
 
 Default = NDPT
 Allowed = int > 0

Help.Tip: Minimum time or depth to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - TIM_INIT
Minimum time or depth to migrate data to.
 
 Default = TSTRT
 Allowed = real
 Units are defined by the velocity.
 For time migration and DMO output global start time = TIM_INIT.

Help.Tip: Minimum depth to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - DEP_INIT
Minimum depth to migrate data to.
 
 Default = TSTRT * DEP_SCALE
 Allowed = real
 Units are defined by the velocity.
 For depth migration the output global start time = DEP_INIT / DEP_SCALE

Help.Tip: Maximum time to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - TIM_LAST
Maximum time to migrate data to.
 
 Default = (NDPT-1)*DT+TSTRT
 Allowed = real>=TIM_INIT
 Units are defined by the velocity.
 For time migration and DMO output global max time = TIM_LAST.

Help.Tip: Maximum depth to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - DEP_LAST
Maximum depth to migrate data to.
 
 Default = ((NDPT-1)*DT+TSTRT) * DEP_SCALE
 Allowed = real >= DEP_INIT
 Units are defined by the velocity.
 For depth migration the output global max time = DEP_LAST / DEP_SCALE

Help.Tip: Time increment to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - TIM_INC
Time increment to migrate data to.
 
 Default = DT
 Allowed = real > 0
 Units are defined by the velocity.
 For time migration and DMO output global time increment = TIM_INC.

Help.Tip: Depth increment to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - DEP_INC
Depth increment to migrate data to.
 
 Default = DT* DEP_SCALE
 Allowed = real > 0
 Units are defined by the velocity.
 For depth migration the output global time increment = DEP_INC / DEP_SCALE

Help.Tip: Number of image locations in the X direction.
Help.Text:
kmig - X_TOT
Number of image locations in the X direction.
 
 Default = 101
 Allowed = int >= 0
 The number of image traces output may be less than X_TOT*Y_TOT
 if no input traces are ever migrated to a portion of the image.

Help.Tip: First X image location to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - X_INIT
First X image location to migrate data to.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_X.

Help.Tip: Last X image location to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - X_LAST
Last X image location to migrate data to.
 
 Default = 100
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_X.

Help.Tip: X image location spacing to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - X_INC
X image location spacing to migrate data to.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_X.

Help.Tip: Number of image locations in the Y direction.
Help.Text:
kmig - Y_TOT
Number of image locations in the Y direction.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int > 0
 The number of image traces output may be less than X_TOT*Y_TOT
 if no input traces are ever migrated to a portion of the image.

Help.Tip: First Y image location to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - Y_INIT
First Y image location to migrate data to.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_Y.

Help.Tip: Last Y image location to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - Y_LAST
Last Y image location to migrate data to.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_Y.

Help.Tip: Y image location spacing to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - Y_INC
Y image location spacing to migrate data to.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_Y.

Help.Tip: Number of offsets in the output image.
Help.Text:
kmig - OFF_TOT
Number of offsets in the output image.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int > 0
 For post stack migration OFF_TOT=1.
 If an input traces offset is outside the range defined by
 OFF_TOT,OFF_INIT,OFF_LAST,OFF_INC the trace is discarded without migrating it.

Help.Tip: Minimum offset in the output image.
Help.Text:
kmig - OFF_INIT
Minimum offset in the output image.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real <= OFF_LAST
 Units are defined by velocity.
 If an input traces offset is outside the range defined by
 OFF_TOT,OFF_INIT,OFF_LAST,OFF_INC the trace is discarded without migrating it.

Help.Tip: Maximum offset in the output image.
Help.Text:
kmig - OFF_LAST
Maximum offset in the output image.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real >= OFF_INIT
 Units are defined by velocity.
 If an input traces offset is outside the range defined by
 OFF_TOT,OFF_INIT,OFF_LAST,OFF_INC the trace is discarded without migrating it.

Help.Tip: Output image offset spacing.
Help.Text:
kmig - OFF_INC
Output image offset spacing.
 
 Default = 200
 Allowed = real > 0
 Units are defined by velocity.
 If an input traces offset is outside the range defined by NOFF, OFFMIN, OFFINC
 the trace is discarded without migrating it.

Help.Tip: Variable depth step option.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_STEP
Variable depth step option.
 
 Default = CONSTANT
 Allowed = CONSTANT - use a constant depth step size of DEP_INC
 Allowed = VARIABLE - use defined arrays of step size - depth - frequency

Help.Tip: What method for interpolating output traces.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_OUT_INT
What method for interpolating output traces.
 
 Default = LINEAR
 Allowed = LINEAR   (Use linear   interpolation for output traces. )
 Allowed = LAGRANGE (Use lagrange interpolation for output traces. )
 Allowed = FFT      (Use fft      interpolation for output traces. )
 Allowed = SINC     (Use sinc     interpolation for output traces. )
 Allowed = NEAREST  (Use nearest  interpolation for output traces. )
 Allowed = NONE     (Use no       interpolation for output traces. )

Help.Tip: Half length of output trace interpolation operator.
Help.Text:
kmig - LEN_OUT_INT
Half length of output trace interpolation operator.
 
 Default = 10
 Allowed = int>0
 When OPT_OUT_INT=SINC the output trace is interpolation from the image trace
 using a sing operator whose leght to either side is
 LEN_OUT_INT * output time or depth samples

Help.Tip: Depth values for variable depth increment.
Help.Text:
kmig - STEP_TIM
Depth values for variable depth increment.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)

Help.Tip: Depth values for variable depth increment.
Help.Text:
kmig - STEP_DEP
Depth values for variable depth increment.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)

Help.Tip: Time increment values at STEP_TIM.
Help.Text:
kmig - STEP_TIM_INC
Time increment values at STEP_TIM.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)

Help.Tip: Depth increment values at STEP_DEP.
Help.Text:
kmig - STEP_DEP_INC
Depth increment values at STEP_DEP.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)

Help.Tip: Whether to use sparse output.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_SPARSE
Whether to use sparse output.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = NO      (Do not use sparse output.)
 Allowed = YES     (Use sparse output.)

Help.Tip: Number of image polygon locations in the X direction.
Help.Text:
kmig - SP_X_TOT
Number of image polygon locations in the X direction.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = int >= 0
 The number of image traces output may be less than SP_X_TOT*SP_Y_TOT
 if no input traces are ever migrated to a portion of the image.

Help.Tip: First X image polygon location to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - SP_X_INIT
First X image polygon location to migrate data to.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_X.

Help.Tip: Last X image polygon location to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - SP_X_LAST
Last X image polygon location to migrate data to.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_X.

Help.Tip: X image polygon location spacing to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - SP_X_INC
X image polygon location spacing to migrate data to.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_X.

Help.Tip: Number of image polygon locations in the Y direction.
Help.Text:
kmig - SP_Y_TOT
Number of image polygon locations in the Y direction.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = int > 0
 The number of image traces output may be less than SP_X_TOT*SP_Y_TOT
 if no input traces are ever migrated to a portion of the image.

Help.Tip: First Y image polygon location to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - SP_Y_INIT
First Y image polygon location to migrate data to.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_Y.

Help.Tip: Last Y image polygon location to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - SP_Y_LAST
Last Y image polygon location to migrate data to.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_Y.

Help.Tip: Y image polygon location spacing to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
kmig - SP_Y_INC
Y image polygon location spacing to migrate data to.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_Y.

Help.Tip: Whether to use polygon arrays, polygon file or no polygon.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_POLY
Whether to use polygon arrays, polygon file or no polygon.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = NONE
 Allowed = ARRAY_POLY
 Allowed = PATH_POLY
 If OPT_POLY = NONE, then no polygon restriction will be used.
 
 If OPT_POLY = ARRAY_POLY, then define polygons by arrays on GUI (X_POLY,
 Y_POLY and ID_POLY).
 
 If OPT_POLY = PATH_POLY, then define polygons by polygon file whose pathname
 is entered in PATH_POLY.

Help.Tip: polygon path name.
Help.Text:
kmig - SELECT_PATH_POLY
polygon path name.

Help.Tip: Polygon flaging file.
Help.Text:
kmig - PATH_POLY
Polygon flaging file.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character

Help.Tip: Image polygon X coordinates.
Help.Text:
kmig - X_POLY
Image polygon X coordinates.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)
 X_POLY. Y_POLY and ID_POLY define a set of closed polygons.
 X_POLY and Y_POLY pairs which share the same value of ID_POLY
 are in the same polygon.  All  X_POLY, Y_POLY  pairs for a single
 polygon should be contiguous.
 X_POLY, Y_POLY and ID_POLY are not defined, all image nodes
 defined by X_TOT, Y_TOT are imaged to and output.
 If X_POLY, Y_POLY and ID_POLY are defined, only the X,Y image
 nodes which fall within those polygons are imaged to.
 All image traces defined by X_TOT, Y_TOT are output but those that
 fall outside the polygon will be dead.

Help.Tip: Image polygon Y coordinates.
Help.Text:
kmig - Y_POLY
Image polygon Y coordinates.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)
 X_POLY. Y_POLY and ID_POLY define a set of closed polygons.
 X_POLY and Y_POLY pairs which share the same value of ID_POLY
 are in the same polygon.  All  X_POLY, Y_POLY  pairs for a single
 polygon should be contiguous.
 X_POLY, Y_POLY and ID_POLY are not defined, all image nodes
 defined by X_TOT, Y_TOT are imaged to and output.
 If X_POLY, Y_POLY and ID_POLY are defined, only the X,Y image
 nodes which fall within those polygons are imaged to.
 All image traces defined by X_TOT, Y_TOT are output but those that
 fall outside the polygon will be dead.

Help.Tip: Image polygon FLAG.
Help.Text:
kmig - ID_POLY
Image polygon FLAG.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)
 X_POLY. Y_POLY and ID_POLY define a set of closed polygons.
 X_POLY and Y_POLY pairs which share the same value of ID_POLY
 are in the same polygon.  All  X_POLY, Y_POLY  pairs for a single
 polygon should be contiguous.
 X_POLY, Y_POLY and ID_POLY are not defined, all image nodes
 defined by X_TOT, Y_TOT are imaged to and output.
 If X_POLY, Y_POLY and ID_POLY are defined, only the X,Y image
 nodes which fall within those polygons are imaged to.
 All image traces defined by X_TOT, Y_TOT are output but those that
 fall outside the polygon will be dead.

Help.Tip: Maximum offset in the X direction in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
kmig - OFF_X_MAX
Maximum offset in the X direction in feet or meters.
 
 Default = -1 = uses a default of (OFF_TOT-1)*OFF_INC+OFF_INIT+OFF_INC/2,
 Allowed = real
 This affects the imaging aperture and the travel time table size.
 Using OFF_X_MAX < 0 uses a default of (OFF_TOT-1)*OFF_INC+OFF_INIT+OFF_INC/2,

Help.Tip: Extra memory usage in the X direction.
Help.Text:
kmig - X_SORT_WIDTH
Extra memory usage in the X direction.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real >= 0.
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 SORT_ORDER = Y_IS_FAST KMIG will keep ( X_SORT_WIDTH / X_INC ) + 1 extra
 image traces in memory.  This allows the use of super sorts to minimize
 travel time table swapping.

Help.Tip: Maximum offset in the Y direction in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
kmig - OFF_Y_MAX
Maximum offset in the Y direction in feet or meters.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 This affects the imaging aperture and the travel time table size.
 Using OFF_Y_MAX < 0 uses a default of (OFF_TOT - 1) * OFF_INC + OFF_INIT

Help.Tip: Extra memory usage in the Y direction.
Help.Text:
kmig - Y_SORT_WIDTH
Extra memory usage in the Y direction.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real >= 0.
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 SORT_ORDER = X_IS_FAST KMIG will keep ( Y_SORT_WIDTH / Y_INC ) + 1 extra
 image traces in memory.  This allows the use of super sorts to minimize
 travel time table swapping.

Help.Tip: Units to use for aperture parameter values.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_AP_UNITS
Units to use for aperture parameter values.
 
 Default = DIST
 Allowed = DIST  (Use feet or meters.)
 Allowed = GRID  (Use grid units (header word 7 and 8 units).)
 Allowed = ANG   (Use angle in degrees.)
 The value of OPT_AP_UNITS determines which arrays of the aperture parameters
 linked arrays are active.

Help.Tip: Constant velocity for converting between time and depth..
Help.Text:
kmig - CONST_VEL_ANG
Constant velocity for converting between time and depth..
 
 Default = 2000.
 Allowed = real > 0.

Help.Tip: Vertical spacing within tables.
Help.Text:
kmig - AP_TIM_INC
Vertical spacing within tables.
 
 Default = -1 = use 10 * TIM_INC
 Allowed = real
 KMIG precomputes a number of tables on a coarse vertical grid.
 AP_TIM_INC defines the vertical spacing within these tables.
 Needed values are computed from these tables via linear interpolation.
 This includes the vertical computational grid for imaging.
 Increasing AP_TIM_INC may reduce memory and improve CPU efficiency at the
 cost of reduced mapping accuracy.
 Units are velocity time units.

Help.Tip: Aperture increment in the x direction, in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
kmig - DIST_AP_X_INC
Aperture increment in the x direction, in feet or meters.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Aperture increment in the x direction, in grid units.
Help.Text:
kmig - GRID_AP_X_INC
Aperture increment in the x direction, in grid units.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Spacing within aperture and travel time table.
Help.Text:
kmig - AP_X_INC
Spacing within aperture and travel time table.
 
 Default = -1 = 5. * X_INC
 Allowed = real
 Units are defined by OPT_AP_UNITS.
 For depth imaging this defines the maximum size of travel time tables.
 The actual size may be smaller depending upon the value of ape_xin
 Increasing this increases memory linearly and CPU nonlinearly.
 The travel time table is computed and saved using a spacing of AP_X_INC
 between locations within the table. The larger AP_X_INC gets the less CPU
 time and memory is recquired at the cost of decreased accuracy.

Help.Tip: Aperture increment in the y direction, in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
kmig - DIST_AP_Y_INC
Aperture increment in the y direction, in feet or meters.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0

Help.Tip: Aperture increment in the y direction, in grid units.
Help.Text:
kmig - GRID_AP_Y_INC
Aperture increment in the y direction, in grid units.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0

Help.Tip: Y spacing within precomputed tables.
Help.Text:
kmig - AP_Y_INC
Y spacing within precomputed tables.
 
 Default = -1 = 5 * Y_INC
 Allowed = real
 KMIG precomputes a number of tables on a coarse horizontal grid.
 AP_Y_INC defines the Y spacing within these tables.
 Needed values are computed from these tables via linear interpolation.
 Units are defined by HDR_Y
 Decreasing AP_Y_INC increases memory linearly and CPU nonlinearly.
 
 For depth migration:
 The travel time table is computed and saved using a spacing of AP_Y_INC
 between locations within the table. The larger AP_Y_INC gets the less CPU
 time and memory is recquired at the cost of decreased accuracy.

Help.Tip: Maximum half-aperture in the x direction, in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
kmig - DIST_AP_X_MAX
Maximum half-aperture in the x direction, in feet or meters.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Maximum half-aperture in the x direction, in grid units.
Help.Text:
kmig - GRID_AP_X_MAX
Maximum half-aperture in the x direction, in grid units.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Max X aperture and travel time table.
Help.Text:
kmig - AP_X_MAX
Max X aperture and travel time table.
 
 Default = DIST_AP_X_MAX
 Allowed = real
 Units are defined by OPT_AP_UNITS.

Help.Tip: Maximum half-aperture in y direction, in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
kmig - DIST_AP_Y_MAX
Maximum half-aperture in y direction, in feet or meters.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0

Help.Tip: Maximum half-aperture in y direction, in grid units.
Help.Text:
kmig - GRID_AP_Y_MAX
Maximum half-aperture in y direction, in grid units.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0

Help.Tip: Max y aperture and travel time table.
Help.Text:
kmig - AP_Y_MAX
Max y aperture and travel time table.
 
 Default = DIST_AP_Y_MAX
 Allowed = real
 Units are defined by OPT_AP_UNITS.

Help.Tip: Time array for time - X distance aperture.
Help.Text:
kmig - TIM_AP_X
Time array for time - X distance aperture.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)

Help.Tip: Depth array for depth - X distance aperture.
Help.Text:
kmig - DEP_AP_X
Depth array for depth - X distance aperture.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)

Help.Tip: Distance array for time or depth - X distance aperture.
Help.Text:
kmig - DIST_AP_X
Distance array for time or depth - X distance aperture.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)

Help.Tip: Array of values of half-aperture to use in x direction.
Help.Text:
kmig - GRID_AP_X
Array of values of half-aperture to use in x direction.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real > 0.0  (linked array)
 Array of time dependent half-aperture values to use in the x direction, in
 grid units.  Actual values used will not exceed AP_X_MAX.

Help.Tip: Angle array for depth - X distance aperture.
Help.Text:
kmig - ANG_AP_X
Angle array for depth - X distance aperture.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)

Help.Tip: Time array for time - Y distance aperture.
Help.Text:
kmig - TIM_AP_Y
Time array for time - Y distance aperture.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)

Velocity model file name.

Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_VEL
Whether to use constant or spatialy varying velocity.
 
 Default = PATH
 Allowed = CONSTANT  Use a constant velocity value of CONST_VEL.
 Allowed = PATH      Use a spatialy varying velocity defined by PATH_VEL.

Help.Tip: Whether to use constant or spatialy varying eta.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_ETA
Whether to use constant or spatialy varying eta.
 
 Default = PATH
 Allowed = CONSTANT  Use a constant value of CONST_ETA.
 Allowed = PATH      Use a spatialy varying eta defined by PATH_ETA.

Whether to use constant or spatialy varying vz.

Help.Tip: Constant migration velocity.
Help.Text:
kmig - CONST_VEL_MIG
Constant migration velocity.
 
 Default = 2000.
 Allowed = real > 0.
 If PATH_VEL is NONE KMIG will use a constant velocity equal to CONST_VEL_MIG.

Help.Tip: Constant steep dip anisotropic coefficient value.
Help.Text:
kmig - CONST_ETA
Constant steep dip anisotropic coefficient value.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 If either PATH_VZ or PATH_ETA are other than NONE or CONST_VZVX or CONST_ETA
 are not equal to 1 and 0 respectively KMIG assumes an anisotropic model.
 Then PATH_VEL is the vx values and the group velocity is
 1/v(a)**2 = cos(a)**2/vz**2 + sin(a)**2/vx**2 * (1 + 2*ETA*cos(a)**2 )
 If TYPE_TABLE_CALC = TIME, PATH_VEL is assumed to be the stacking velocity.
 Otherwise, PATH_VEL is assumed to be the horizontal interval velocity.
 If PATH_VZ is NONE the vertical velocity is CONST_VZVX times the horizontal
 velocity.
 If PATH_ETA is NONE the steep dip anisotropic coefficient is CONST_ETA
 CONST_VZVX=1,CONST_ETA=0 are the isotropic limits.

Help.Tip: Constant vertical / horizontal velocity ratio.
Help.Text:
kmig - CONST_VZVX
Constant vertical / horizontal velocity ratio.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = real > 0.
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 If either PATH_VZ or PATH_ETA are other than NONE
 or CONST_VZVX or CONST_ETA are not
 equal to 1 and 0 respectively KMIG assumes an anisotropic model.
 Then PATH_VEL is the vx values and the group velocity is
 1/v(a)**2 = cos(a)**2/vz**2 + sin(a)**2/vx**2 * (1 + 2*ETA*cos(a)**2 )
 If TYPE_TABLE_CALC = TIME, PATH_VEL is assumed to be the stacking velocity.
 Otherwise, PATH_VEL is assumed to be the horizontal interval velocity.
 If PATH_VZ is NONE the vertical velocity is CONST_VZVX times the horizontal
 velocity.
 If PATH_ETA is NONE the steep dip anisotropic coefficient is CONST_ETA
 CONST_VZVX=1,CONST_ETA=0 are the isotropic limits.

Help.Tip: Depth velocity gradient is measured from.
Help.Text:
kmig - DEPTH_VEL_MIG
Depth velocity gradient is measured from.
 
 Default = 0.
 Allowed = real

Help.Tip: Whether to use constant or spatialy varying X_SIN.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_X_SIN
Whether to use constant or spatialy varying X_SIN.
 
 Default = PATH
 Allowed = CONSTANT  Use a constant X_SIN value of CONST_X_SIN.
 Allowed = PATH      Use a spatialy X_SIN varying defined by PATH_X_SIN.
 The X_SIN coefficient is the sine of the anisotropic coefficient dip angle
 projected into the x,z plane.
 For a horizontal geometry x_sin = y_sin = 0.
 For a 30 degree dip from the horizontal in the x direction, x_sin = .5
 For a 45 degree dip from the horizontal in the x direction, x_sin = .7071
 The true dip of the anisotropic coefficient from the z axis is:
 asin ( sqrt ( 1. - x_sin**2 - y_sin**2 ) )

Help.Tip: Whether to use constant or spatialy varying Y_SIN.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_Y_SIN
Whether to use constant or spatialy varying Y_SIN.
 
 Default = PATH
 Allowed = CONSTANT  Use a constant Y_SIN value of CONST_Y_SIN.
 Allowed = PATH      Use a spatialy Y_SIN varying defined by PATH_Y_SIN.
 The Y_SIN coefficient is the sine of the anisotropic coefficient dip angle
 projected into the y,z plane.
 For a horizontal geometry x_sin = y_sin = 0.
 For a 30 degree dip from the horizontal in the y direction, y_sin = .5
 For a 45 degree dip from the horizontal in the y direction, y_sin = .7071
 The true dip of the anisotropic coefficient from the z axis is:
 asin ( sqrt ( 1. - x_sin**2 - y_sin**2 ) )

 For a 45 degree dip from the horizontal in the x direction, x_sin = .7071
 The true dip of the anisotropic coefficient from the z axis is:
 asin ( sqrt ( 1. - x_sin**2 - y_sin**2 ) )

Convert input velocity from stack to nmo for anisotropic time mig.

Help.Text:
kmig - V_SRC_REC
Ratio of source velocity to receiver Vs / Vr.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = real > 0.
 Used for depth migrating p to s converted waves.
 This will adjust apertures, amplitude and aliasing for p to s converted waves.

Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_VA
Whether migration velocity analysis (FCTR_VEL array) is active.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES
 Allowed = NO
 If OPT_VA = YES, then the FCTR_VEL array is active for migration velocity
 analysis.
 
 If OPT_VA = NO, then the FCTR_VEL array is inactive.

Help.Tip: Velocity scale factors.
Help.Text:
kmig - FCTR_VEL
Velocity scale factors.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = real (array) > 0
 Multiple images are constructed for the different imaging velocity scales
 in FCTR_VEL.
 The time imaging velocity is the input velocity * FCTR_VEL
 The depth imaging travel time is
 the computed time for the input velocity / FCTR_VEL

Help.Tip: Eta scale factors.
Help.Text:
kmig - FCTR_ETA
Eta scale factors.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = real (array) > 0
 Multiple images are constructed for the different imaging velocity scales
 in Velocity .
 The time imaging velocity is the input eta * FCTR_ETA
 The depth imaging travel time is
 the computed time for the input velocity / FCTR_ETA
 Note for depth imaging FCTR_ETA=FCTR_VEL

Help.Tip: Type of image node divison.
Help.Text:
kmig - DIV_TYPE
Type of image node divison.
 
 Default = ROUND
 Allowed = ROUND for round robin distribution
 Allowed = BLOCK for block distribution
 Allowed = ZERO  to distrubte to pe 0 only.
 Allowed = ALL   to distrubte to all pes.
 
 DIV_TYPE defines the type of Y node division among pes
   0 = round robin, 1 = block, 2 = 0 only, 3 = all
 
   DIV_TYPE=ROUND, Round robin division
   means for a job with NY_MIG=100, Number of PES=4
   pe 0 gets Y nodes 1,5, 9,..., 97
   pe 1 gets Y nodes 2,6,10,..., 98
   pe 2 gets Y nodes 3,7,11,..., 99
   pe 3 gets Y nodes 4,8,12,...,100
 
   DIV_TYPE=BLOCK, Block division
   means for a job with NY_MIG=100, Number of PES=4
   pe 0 gets Y nodes  1- 25
   pe 1 gets Y nodes 26- 50
   pe 2 gets Y nodes 51- 75
   pe 3 gets Y nodes 76-100
 
   DIV_TYPE=ZERO, 0 only division
   means for a job with NY_MIG=100, Number of PES=4
   pe 0 gets Y nodes  1-100
   pe 1 gets Y nodes  0-  0
   pe 2 gets Y nodes  0-  0
   pe 3 gets Y nodes  0-  0
 
   DIV_TYPE=ALL, all division
   means for a job with NY_MIG=100, Number of PES=4
   pe 0 gets Y nodes  1-100
   pe 1 gets Y nodes  1-100
   pe 2 gets Y nodes  1-100
   pe 3 gets Y nodes  1-100

kmig - PRINT_MEMORY
Print details of memory allocation.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES - Turn print on.
 Allowed = NO  - Turn print off.

Help.Tip: Print debug information.
Help.Text:
kmig - PRINT_DEBUG
Print debug information.
 
 Default = BRIEF
 Allowed = NONE     - no debug information is printed.
 Allowed = BRIEF    - default debug information is printed.
 Allowed = DETAILED - detailed debug information is printed.
 Allowed = DEBUG    - full debug information is printed.

Help.Tip: Number of cpus per parallel processing group.
Help.Text:
kmig - CPUS_PER_GROUP
Number of cpus per parallel processing group.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = 1 <= int <= number pes in job
 fxshot will break the NUM_CPUS = number of pes in the job, processors
 into PAR_GROUPS groups of processors.
 Each group will have a maximum of CPUS_PER_GROUP proecessors in the job,
 and will image a subset of the input traces and construct
 an image indiependantly from th eother groups.  At the end
 of processing the separate images will be summed to gether
 by fxshot and the result output on all pes.
 It is strongly reccommended that you set the number of
 processors, NUM_CPUS, in a job be a multiple of CPUS_PER_GROUP,
 so each group will have the same number of processors.  It is
 also best that all processors in a job be the same speed.
 
 The maximum number of processors in any group is :
 m_pe_grp = ( NUM_CPUS + par_groups - 1 ) / par_groups
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_2 = par_groups * m_pe_grp - NUM_CPUS
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_1 = NUM_CPUS - n_pe_grp_2

Help.Tip: Number of parallel processing groups.
Help.Text:
kmig - PAR_GROUPS
Number of parallel processing groups.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = 1 <= int <= number pes in job
 fxshot will break the NUM_CPUS = number of pes in the job, processors
 into PAR_GROUPS groups of processors.
 Each group will have a maximum of CPUS_PER_GROUP proecessors in the job,
 and will image a subset of the input traces and construct
 an image indiependantly from th eother groups.  At the end
 of processing the separate images will be summed to gether
 by fxshot and the result output on all pes.
 It is strongly reccommended that you set the number of
 processors, NUM_CPUS, in a job be a multiple of CPUS_PER_GROUP,
 so each group will have the same number of processors.  It is
 also best that all processors in a job be the same speed.
 
 The maximum number of processors in any group is :
 m_pe_grp = ( NUM_CPUS + par_groups - 1 ) / par_groups
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_2 = par_groups * m_pe_grp - NUM_CPUS
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_1 = NUM_CPUS - n_pe_grp_2

Help.Tip: Total number of cpus in job.
Help.Text:
kmig - NUM_CPUS
Total number of cpus in job.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = 1 <= int <= number pes in job
 fxshot will break the NUM_CPUS = number of pes in the job, processors
 into PAR_GROUPS groups of processors.
 Each group will have a maximum of CPUS_PER_GROUP proecessors in the job,
 and will image a subset of the input traces and construct
 an image indiependantly from th eother groups.  At the end
 of processing the separate images will be summed to gether
 by fxshot and the result output on all pes.
 It is strongly reccommended that you set the number of
 processors, NUM_CPUS, in a job be a multiple of CPUS_PER_GROUP,
 so each group will have the same number of processors.  It is
 also best that all processors in a job be the same speed.
 
 The maximum number of processors in any group is :
 m_pe_grp = ( NUM_CPUS + par_groups - 1 ) / par_groups
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_2 = par_groups * m_pe_grp - NUM_CPUS
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_1 = NUM_CPUS - n_pe_grp_2

Help.Tip: Image all input traces as a single group.
Help.Text:
kmig - ONE_IMAGE
Image all input traces as a single group.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = NO  KMIG will output a different image volume for each input offs*
 Allowed = YES KMIG will output a single image volume for all input traces.

Help.Tip: Output all image traces defined by the image grid.
Help.Text:
kmig - ALL_OUT
Output all image traces defined by the image grid.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES KMIG will output all image traces defined by the X,Y grid.
 Allowed = NO  KMIG will output only those image trace which have an input
 within the image bin.
 Allowed = POLY_YES KMIG will output all image traces defined by the X,Y grid.
 which fall within the polygons defined by X_POLY nad Y_POLY.
 Allowed = POLY_NO  KMIG will output only those image trace which have an
 input trace within the image bin and which fall within the polygons defined
 by X_POLY nad Y_POLY.

kmig - OPT_OUTPUT
Type of output parameter.
 
 Default = IMAGE
 Allowed = IMAGE     (Production output of the normal migration image.)
 Allowed = VELOCITY  (Diagnostic output of the migration velocity field.)
 Allowed = TIME      (Diagnostic output of the two-way travel time.)
 Allowed = ANTIALIAS (Diagnostic output of the antialias coefficient)

Help.Tip: What method for interpolating output traces.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_MAP_APPLY
What method for interpolating output traces.
 
 Default = MAP_APPLY_I
 Allowed = MAP_APPLY_C Use MAP_APPLY_C   which does not include gradients.
 Allowed = MAP_APPLY_F Use MAP_APPLY_F   which does not include gradients.
 Allowed = MAP_APPLY_G Use MAP_APPLY_G   which does     include gradients.
 Allowed = MAP_APPLY_H Use MAP_APPLY_H   which includes gradients and paz.
 Allowed = MAP_APPLY_I Use MAP_APPLY_H_C which includes gradients and paz.
 KMIG will use MAP_APPLY_C when MIG_TYPE = DMO or OPT_OUTPUT .ne. IMAGE

Help.Tip: What level of map print.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_MAP_PRINT
What level of map print.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = int>= 0
 Higher values of OPT_MAP_PRINT print the map values at more stages
 in the computation.
 opt_map_print .eq. -1 .or. opt_map_print .ge. 1 after ksum_map_compute.
 opt_map_print .eq. -2 .or. opt_map_print .ge. 2 after ksum_map_gradient.
 opt_map_print .eq. -3 .or. opt_map_print .ge. 3 after ksum_paz_interpolate.
 opt_map_print .eq. -4 .or. opt_map_print .ge. 4 after ksum_mute_turn.
 opt_map_print .eq. -5 .or. opt_map_print .ge. 5 after ksum_doppler_apply.
 opt_map_print .eq. -6 .or. opt_map_print .ge. 6 after ksum_map_apply.
 Maps for x,y image node locations FIRST_MAP_PRINT to LAST_MAP_PRINT
 are printed.

Help.Tip: First x,y imag enode to print map for.
Help.Text:
kmig - FIRST_MAP_PRINT
First x,y imag enode to print map for.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int>= 0
 Maps for x,y image node locations FIRST_MAP_PRINT to LAST_MAP_PRINT
 are printed.

Help.Tip: Last x,y imag enode to print map for.
Help.Text:
kmig - LAST_MAP_PRINT
Last x,y imag enode to print map for.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int>= 0
 Maps for x,y image node locations FIRST_MAP_PRINT to LAST_MAP_PRINT
 are printed.

Help.Tip: Maximum number of anti-alias filters to use.
Help.Text:
kmig - NUM_AA
Maximum number of anti-alias filters to use.
 
 Default = 31
 Allowed = int > 0
 KMIG uses the Claerbout integration method for anti-aliasing which makes a
 number of copies of the input trace, each with a different anti-alias filter
 applied.
 
 NUM_AA = 31 is usually sufficient, NUM_AA = 40 is probably excessive.

Help.Tip: Effective input trace physical spacing, in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
kmig - DIST_AA
Effective input trace physical spacing, in feet or meters.
 
 Default = -1
 Allowed = real > 0.0, -1 means compute default from X_INC
 The effective input trace physical spacing, in feet or meters, for use in
 calculating the anti-alias filter.  It should be roughly the average of
 the X and the Y spacing of input traces.  Larger distances
 produce more severe anti-aliasing, so using the larger of the X or the
 Y output trace spacing is the most conservative approach.

Help.Tip: Antialias normalization.
Help.Text:
kmig - NORM_AA
Antialias normalization.
 
 Default = MAX_AMP
 Allowed = MAX_AMP Preserve maximum ampplitude.
 Allowed = NONE    No antialias nrmaliazation.

Help.Tip: Frequency filter phase.
Help.Text:
kmig - PHASE_FILT
Frequency filter phase.
 
 Default = -999 - defaults to 45 for 2D and 90. for 3D.
 Allowed = real
 PHASE_FILT is used to set the type of migration phase shift.
 In theory: PHASE_FILT=45. for 2D and 90. for 3D.
 However if you are testing a migration with a single input 3D line
 to a single output 3D line PHASE_FILT=45.

Help.Tip: Frequency filter power.
Help.Text:
kmig - PWR_FILT
Frequency filter power.
 
 Default = -999 - defaults to .5 for 2D and 1 for 3D.
 Allowed = real
 Before migration each input trace is filtered by a function of the form
 A(F) = F ** PWR_FILT
 Where F is the frequency.
 In theory: PHASE_FILT=45. for 2D and 90. for 3D.
 PWR_FILT=-999. uses these values.
 Using PWR_FILT=.5 yields the traditional Kirchhoff filter for 2D.
 Using PWR_FILT=1. yields the traditional Kirchhoff filter for 3D.
 Using PWR_FILT=3  accentuates higer frequencies.
 Using PWR_FILT=0  accentuates lower frequencies.

Help.Tip: Use ppio for trace io.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_USE_PPIO
Use ppio for trace io.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES use ppio routines.
 Allowed = NO use TRCIO routines.

Help.Tip: Mute events whose input time decreases with output time or depth.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_MUTE_TURN
Mute events whose input time decreases with output time or depth.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES, NO
 If OPT_MUTE_TURN = NO,  then allow any input time to output relation ship.
 If OPT_MUTE_TURN = YES, then mute when input time decreases
                         with output time or depth.

Help.Tip: Whether a stretch mute (Doppler mute) is used.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_DOPP
Whether a stretch mute (Doppler mute) is used.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES, NO
 If OPT_DOPP = YES, then use a stretch mute.
 If OPT_DOPP = NO,  then do not use a stretch mute.

Help.Tip: DOPPLER mute stretch factor.
Help.Text:
kmig - DOPPLER
DOPPLER mute stretch factor.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real >= 0
 DOPPLER is used to mute migration events which are stretched beyond
 a doppler limit.  For time migration this is simply the ratio of
 input_time / output time.  for depth migrations this is the ratio of
 input_time / (2. * output_depth / average_velocity) where
 average_vvelocity is averaged over all x,y locations at each depth
 point.
 An input value of DOPPLER<=0 disables the doppler muting.
 Increasing the value of DOPPLER increases the amount of migration
 stretch allowed before muting occurs.

Help.Tip: Distance perpindicular to trace azimuth to broadcast trace.
Help.Text:
kmig - DMO_DISTANCE
Distance perpindicular to trace azimuth to broadcast trace.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Map each output trace to distance of DMO_DISTANCE perpindicular to
 the source reciever line.
 Units are defined in distance units.

Help.Tip: Amplitude scale at DMO_DISTANCE from source receiver line.
Help.Text:
kmig - DMO_SCALE
Amplitude scale at DMO_DISTANCE from source receiver line.
 
 Default = .8
 Allowed = 0. - 1.
 Mapping an output trace to a larger distance perpindicular to more than one
 bin will reduce spatial aliasing of DMO hence increase the accuracy of
 inverse DMO.

Help.Tip: Azimuth angle for inver DMO and inver time migration.
Help.Text:
kmig - AZIMUTH
Azimuth angle for inver DMO and inver time migration.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Units are defined in degree.
 The source and receiver locations will be adjusted
 based on offset and azimuth angle.

Help.Tip: Factor to use in interpolating the input trace samples.
Help.Text:
kmig - DT_INTERP
Factor to use in interpolating the input trace samples.
 
 Default = -1.
 Allowed = real >= dt_inp
 Input trace samples are interpolated to DT_INTERP prior to
 migration to insure adequate temporal resolution of the output image.
 Normally interpolation to a 1 ms or 2 ms sample interval is adequate.
 DT_INTERP * integer = input time increment.
 DT_INTERP<0 yields DT_INTERP = input time increment / 4.

Help.Tip: Number of input traces between migration status prints.
Help.Text:
kmig - PRINT_INC
Number of input traces between migration status prints.
 
 Default = 1000
 Allowed = int > 0

Help.Tip: Type of sum reduce at output.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_SUM_REDUCE
Type of sum reduce at output.
 
 Default = GLOBAL
 Allowed = LOCAL

Help.Tip: Type of amplitude treatment.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_AMPLITUDE
Type of amplitude treatment.
 
 Default = HPHILLIPS
 Allowed = HCONOCO
 Allowed = VOFZ
 Allowed = USER
 To get the heritage Conoco   ampltiude scaling use OPT_AMPLITUDE = HCONOCO
 To get the heritage Phillips ampltiude scaling use OPT_AMPLITUDE = HPHILLIPS
 To get a vofz raytraced      ampltiude scaling use OPT_AMPLITUDE = VOFZ
 To get some other            amplitude scaling use OPT_AMPLITUDE = USER
 OPT_AMPLITUDE = VOFZ_3D applies a 2D v(z) amplitude correction and sets
 OPT_AMP_COSINE = VOFZ_2D, PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP = +0., PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT = -0.
 OPT_AMPLITUDE = VOFZ_2D applies a 3D v(z) amplitude correction and sets
 OPT_AMP_COSINE = VOFZ_2D, PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP = +0., PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT = -0.
 OPT_AMPLITUDE = VOFZ_2.5d applies a 2.5d v(z) amplitude correction and sets
 OPT_AMP_COSINE = VOFZ_2.5D, PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP = +0., PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT = -0.
 OPT_AMPLITUDE  = HCONOCO sets
 OPT_AMP_COSINE = HCONOCO,   PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP = +0., PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT = -0.
 OPT_AMPLITUDE  = HPHILLIPS sets
 OPT_AMP_COSINE = HPHILLIPS, PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP = +1., PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT = -1.
 OPT_AMPLITUDE  = USER allows an arbitray combination of parameters.
 OPT_AMP_COSINE, PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP, PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT
 The v(z) amplitude scaling computes a v(z) curved ray amplitude correction
 This assumes no divergence correction has been applied to the input data
 prior to input to imaging.
 Heritage Conoco's ampltiude scaling was cos(dip)
 this assumes a divergence correction has been applied to the input data
 prior to input to imaging and zero offset.
 Heritage Philip's ampltiude scaling was
 ( time / depth ) * cos(source)**2+cos(reciever)**2)
 this assumes no divergence correction has been applied to the input data
 prior to input to imaging.

Help.Tip: Type of cosine dip samplitude scaling.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_AMP_COSINE
Type of cosine dip samplitude scaling.
 
 Default = HCONOCO
 Allowed = HPHILLIPS
 Allowed = VOFZ_2D
 Allowed = VOFZ_2.5D
 Allowed = VOFZ_3D

Help.Tip: Scale input data by (TIME-MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP.
Help.Text:
kmig - PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP
Scale input data by (TIME-MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Apply an amplitude scaling of (TIME - MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP) ** PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP
 to each input trace before imaging.
 Using PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP = 0. yields no amplitude scaling before imaging.

Help.Tip: Scale input data by (TIME-MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP.
Help.Text:
kmig - MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP
Scale input data by (TIME-MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Apply an amplitude scaling of (TIME - MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP) ** PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP
 to each input trace before imaging.
 Using PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP = 0. yields no amplitude scaling before imaging.

Help.Tip: Scale output data by (DEPTH-MIN_AMP_SCALE_OUT)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT.
Help.Text:
kmig - PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT
Scale output data by (DEPTH-MIN_AMP_SCALE_OUT)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Apply an amplitude scaling of (DEPTH - MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP) ** PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT
 to each output trace after imaging.
 Using PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT = 0. yields no amplitude scaling after imaging.
 For time migration DEPTH will be output time.

Help.Tip: Scale output data by (DEPTH-MIN_AMP_SCALE_OUT)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT.
Help.Text:
kmig - MIN_AMP_SCALE_OUT
Scale output data by (DEPTH-MIN_AMP_SCALE_OUT)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Apply an amplitude scaling of (DEPTH - MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP) ** PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT
 to each output trace after imaging.
 Using PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT = 0. yields no amplitude scaling after imaging.
 For time migration DEPTH will be output time.

Help.Tip: Whether stack scaling is used.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_FOS_SCALE
Whether stack scaling is used.
 
 Default = NO
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES stack scaling is used.
 Allowed = NO  stack scaling is not used
               and fold of stack sampling is disabled.

Help.Tip: Exponent for fold of stack scaling.
Help.Text:
kmig - FOS_PWR
Exponent for fold of stack scaling.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = real
 Fold of stack amplitude scaler= fold**FOS_PWR

Help.Tip: Lateral image sum taper distance in spatial units.
Help.Text:
kmig - XY_TAPER
Lateral image sum taper distance in spatial units.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real >= 0

Help.Tip: Number of times for sampling fold of stack.
Help.Text:
kmig - FOS_TIM_TOT
Number of times for sampling fold of stack.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = int > 0

Help.Tip: Number of times for sampling fold of stack.
Help.Text:
kmig - FOS_DEP_TOT
Number of times for sampling fold of stack.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = int > 0

Help.Tip: Increment between times to sample fold of stack, in seconds.
Help.Text:
kmig - FOS_TIM_INC
Increment between times to sample fold of stack, in seconds.
 
 Default = 0.1
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Increment between times to sample fold of stack, in seconds.
Help.Text:
kmig - FOS_DEP_INC
Increment between times to sample fold of stack, in seconds.
 
 Default = 0.1
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Image sum taper distance in time or depth units.
Help.Text:
kmig - TIM_TAPER
Image sum taper distance in time or depth units.
 
 Default = -1, defaults to TIM_TAPER = 15 * TIME_INC
 Allowed = -1, real > 0

Help.Tip: Image sum taper distance in time or depth units.
Help.Text:
kmig - DEP_TAPER
Image sum taper distance in time or depth units.
 
 Default = -1, defaults to DEP_TAPER = 15 * DEP_INC
 Allowed = -1, real > 0

Help.Tip: First time for sampling fold of stack, in seconds.
Help.Text:
kmig - FOS_TIM_INIT
First time for sampling fold of stack, in seconds.
 
 Default = TSTRT
 Allowed = real >= TSTRT

Help.Tip: First time for sampling fold of stack, in seconds.
Help.Text:
kmig - FOS_DEP_INIT
First time for sampling fold of stack, in seconds.
 
 Default = TSTRT
 Allowed = real >= TSTRT

Help.Tip: Last time for sampling fold of stack, in seconds.
Help.Text:
kmig - FOS_TIM_LAST
Last time for sampling fold of stack, in seconds.
 
 Default = end of trace
 Allowed = real >= FOS_TIM_INIT

Help.Tip: Last time for sampling fold of stack, in seconds.
Help.Text:
kmig - FOS_DEP_LAST
Last time for sampling fold of stack, in seconds.
 
 Default = end of trace
 Allowed = real >= FOS_DEP_INIT

Border.title: Travel time table file name definition

Help.Tip: Press button to reset table parameters.
Help.Text:
kmig - TABLE_RESET
Press button to reset table parameters.
 
 When the TABLE_RESET button is pressed and TABLE_INITIALIZE=YES, the
 parameters defining the travel time tables are read from the
 table header file.

Help.Tip: Type of travel time table operation.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_TABLE_OPERATION
Type of travel time table operation.
 
 Default = IMAGE
 Allowed = IMAGE      - Image data.
 Allowed = INITIALIZE - Initialize tables.
 Allowed = COMPUTE    - Compute tables.
 Allowed = CHECK      - Check tables.
 Allowed = ALL        - INITALIZE, and COMPUTE Tables, and IMAGE data.
 Allowed = USER       - User defined.
 Note you cannot INITALIZE or COMPUTE Tables, and IMAGE data in a parallel job.
 Not used for time migration and DMO.

Help.Tip: Travel time calculation method.
Help.Text:
kmig - TYPE_TABLE_CALC
Travel time calculation method.
 
 Default = EIKONAL
 Allowed = EIKONAL  - Eikonal method.  2D and 3D isotropic.
 Allowed = EIKONALA - Eikonal method.  2D and 3D anisotropic.
 Allowed = EIKONGRP - Eikonal method.  2D and 3D anisotropic using
                      analytical group velocity.
 Allowed = RAYTRACE - Raytracing, 2D and 3D.
 Allowed = RAYTRVTI - Raytracing, 2D and 3D VTI.
 Allowed = RAYSHVTI - Raytracing, 2D and 3D VTI incuddeing shear effects.
 Allowed = VOFZ     - V(Z) raytraceing, 2D and 3D.
 Allowed = STRAIGHT - Straight rays, 2D and 3D.
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 If KMIG ever has an error during creating a travel time table
 it will stop migrating traces and flush out the remaining
 partialy completed image traces.
 partialy completed image traces.
 RAYSHVTI is not operational yet.

Help.Tip: Zero travel time table space.
Help.Text:
kmig - TABLE_INITIALIZE
Zero travel time table space.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = NO  KMIG will not zero the travel time table space.
 Allowed = YES KMIG will     zero  the travel time table space.

Help.Tip: Compute travel time tables.
Help.Text:
kmig - TABLE_COMPUTE
Compute travel time tables.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = NO  KMIG will not compute travel time tables.
 Allowed = YES KMIG will     compute travel time tables.
 Allowed = all KMIG will     compute ALL travel time tables.
 If TABLE_COMPUTE=YES KMIG will precompute tables FIRST_TABLE - LAST_TABLE
 If TABLE_COMPUTE=ALL KMIG will precompute all tables.

Help.Tip: Image input data.
Help.Text:
kmig - TABLE_IMAGE
Image input data.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = NO  KMIG will not image input data.
 Allowed = YES KMIG will     image input data.

Help.Tip: Test tables before computing.
Help.Text:
kmig - TABLE_TEST
Test tables before computing.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES, Test tables and only compute if bad.
 Allowed = NO,  Do not test tables, compute all tables.
 
 TABLE_COMPUTE must be YES or ALL for TABLE_TEST to have any effect.
 
 If TABLE_TEST=YES, KDMIG and KMIG will test each travel time table between
 FIRST_TABLE to LAST_TABLE before computing it.  If the table does not pass
 the check process it will be recomputed.  If it does pass the check process
 it will not be recomputed.
 
 Note during the check process KTABLE looks at each tables label section
 for information on the table location.
 If this is correct, placed there when the table is first computed,
 the check process is passed.
 If it is not correct the check process is failed.
 This can be due to changing table characteristics such as size,
 a bad disk or if the table has never been computed.

Help.Tip: Check travel time table space.
Help.Text:
kmig - TABLE_CHECK
Check travel time table space.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = NO  KMIG will not check the travel time table space.
 Allowed = YES KMIG will     check the travel time table space.

Help.Tip: Travel time computation spactial increment in distance units.
Help.Text:
kmig - TABLE_COMP_INC
Travel time computation spactial increment in distance units.
 
 Default = -1 = AP_DEP_INC
 Allowed = real
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 Using -1 computes a default value of AP_DEP_INC.

Help.Tip: Number of travel time table datums.
Help.Text:
kmig - NUM_DATUMS
Number of travel time table datums.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = 1, 2
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 For infomration only.  Thes user can not modify this.
 NUM_TABLES = NUM_DATUMS * TABLES_PER_DATUM

Help.Tip: Total number of travel time table.
Help.Text:
kmig - NUM_TABLES
Total number of travel time table.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int >= 1
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 For infomration only.  Thes user can not modify this.
 NUM_TABLES = NUM_DATUMS * TABLES_PER_DATUM

Help.Tip: Total number of source travel time table.
Help.Text:
kmig - TABLES_PER_DATUM
Total number of source travel time table.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int >= 1
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 For infomration only.  Thes user can not modify this.
 NUM_TABLES = NUM_DATUMS * TABLES_PER_DATUM

Help.Tip: First travel time table to compute in this job.
Help.Text:
kmig - FIRST_TABLE
First travel time table to compute in this job.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int >= 1
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 If TABLE_COMPUTE=YES KMIG will precompute tables FIRST_TABLE - LAST_TABLE
 If TABLE_COMPUTE=ALL KMIG will precompute all tables.

Help.Tip: Last travel time table to compute in this job.
Help.Text:
kmig - LAST_TABLE
Last travel time table to compute in this job.
 
 Default = 999999999
 Allowed = int >= 0
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 If TABLE_COMPUTE=YES KMIG will compute tables FIRST_TABLE - LAST_TABLE
 If TABLE_COMPUTE=ALL KMIG will precompute all tables.

Help.Tip: Use the nearest travel time table.
Help.Text:
kmig - NEAREST_TABLE
Use the nearest travel time table.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = NO   KMIG will abort if a needed travel time table falls
 outside the range defined in the travel time table file.
 Allowed = YES KMIG will use the nearest travel time table in the file.
 Not used for time migration and DMO.

Help.Tip: Maximum travel time table size in gigabytes.
Help.Text:
kmig - TABLE_SIZE
Maximum travel time table size in gigabytes.
 
 Default = 2
 Allowed = real > 0.
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 Maximum travel time table size in gigabytes.
 The actual number of files used will depend upon this value
 and the total size of all the travel time tables.
 On 32 bit machines the max file size is   2 Gigabytes.
 The actual file names will be PATH_TABLE with a number apendded to the end.

Help.Tip: Travel time table shape, NORMAL, and CUBE are valid.
Help.Text:
kmig - TABLE_SHAPE
Travel time table shape, NORMAL, and CUBE are valid.
 
 Default = NORMAL
 Allowed = NORMAL gives a memory and disk efficent, complicated table shape.
 Allowed = CUBE yields a simple rectangular grid.
 Not used for time migration and DMO.

Help.Tip: Apply static correction to travel times during interpolation.
Help.Text:
kmig - TABLE_STATIC
Apply static correction to travel times during interpolation.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES - YES static correction is applied.
 Allowed = NO  - No  static correction is applied.
 Not used for time migration and DMO.

Help.Tip: Number of parameters to compute and store in travel time tables.
Help.Text:
kmig - TABLE_PARMS
Number of parameters to compute and store in travel time tables.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = 1 = Travel times only.
 Allowed = 2 = Travel times and amplitudes.
 Allowed = 3 = Travel times, amplitudes and phases.
 Use 3 for raytracing.
 Not used for time migration and DMO.

Help.Tip: Travel time table order, BLOCK, ROUND_ROBIN are valid.
Help.Text:
kmig - TABLE_ORDER
Travel time table order, BLOCK, ROUND_ROBIN are valid.
 
 Default = ROUND_ROBIN
 Allowed = BLOCK       assigns tables to disk in BLOCK order
 Allowed = ROUND_ROBIN assigns tables to disk in ROUND ROBIN order
 Not used for time migration and DMO.

Help.Tip: Travel time interpolation, before or during imaging.
Help.Text:
kmig - TABLE_INTERPOLATE
Travel time interpolation, before or during imaging.
 
 Default = LOCAL
 Allowed = LOCAL  Interpolate those table nodes which are required.
 Allowed = GLOBAL Interpolate all table nodes .

Help.Tip: number of bits to save for each travel time value on disk.
Help.Text:
kmig - DISK_PACK
number of bits to save for each travel time value on disk.
 
 Default = 32
 Allowed = 1 <= int <= 32
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 number of bits to save for each travel time value on disk.
 Using DISK_PACK=1 uses the native word length.
 For production work use MEMORY_PACK=DISK_PACK.

Help.Tip: number of bits to save for each travel time value in memory.
Help.Text:
kmig - MEMORY_PACK
number of bits to save for each travel time value in memory.
 
 Default = 32
 Allowed = 1 <= int <= 32
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 Using MEMORY_PACK =1 uses the native word length.
 For production work use MEMORY_PACK=DISK_PACK.

Help.Tip: Spherical interpolation scale factor.
Help.Text:
kmig - SPHERICAL_SCALE
Spherical interpolation scale factor.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = 0 <= real
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 For depth migration KMIG wil interpolate the coarse grid travel times
 from the source and receiver travel times.  If the distance to the top of
 the coarse grid to the source or receiver is less than TERP_DISTANCE
 KMIG will compute the travel times by first computing the average slowness
 from the source or receiver to each table grid node and then use that
 average slowness to compute the travel time to the coarse grid nodes.
 TERP_DISTANCE is the distance at which the difference between linearly and
 sphericaly interpolated travel times using an average velocity model is less
 than DT * SPHERICAL_SCALE.
 Using SPHERICAL_SCALE=0.      means there will be no linear    interpolation.
 Using SPHERICAL_SCALE=999999. means there will be no spherical interpolation.

Help.Tip: Write ray QC files.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_TAB_QC
Write ray QC files.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = NO   Do not write ray QC files.
 Allowed = YES  Write ray QC files for the travel time tables
                between FIRST_TAB_QC and LAST_TAB_QC.
 
 If OPT_TAB_QC = YES KMIG will write a number of QC files for the
 first travel time table computed via raytraceing on the root pe.
 
 These QC files will begin a suffix defined by parameter ROOT_TAB_QC with
 a varyiable suffix which changes with the qc coefficient.
 Coeffiecients are only output if they are used during a compuation.
 Hence anisotropic ocefficients ar enot output for isotropic computations
 and the amplitude is output only when the amplitude
 is used as a ray slection criteria.
 
 xxxxx will be the travel time table index.
 
 The following QC files will all have the spatial grid characteristics
 of the first travel time table computed by the root pe.
 
 xxxxx_unf.trc - travel time field before undfined values have been filled in.
 xxxxx_tim.trc - travel time field after  undfined values have been filled in.
 xxxxx_amp.trc - amplitude field
 xxxxx_phs.trc - phase field - currently never computed
 xxxxx_vxt.trc - min max velocity field used when
 xxxxx_rst.trc - ray path length
 xxxxx_dtt.trc - ray trace time step increment.
 
 The following QC files will all have the spatial grid characteristics
 of the velocity field for first travel time table computed by the root pe.
 
 xxxxx_vxv.trc - horizontal velocity field
 xxxxx_vev.trc - eta coefficient field
 xxxxx_vzv.trc - vertical velocity field
 xxxxx_sxv.trc - x dip field
 xxxxx_syv.trc - y dip field
 xxxxx_dtv.trc - ray trace time step increment.
 
 
 The following QC files will all have the spatial grid characteristics
 the first travel time table  and will be output if tables are packed
 
 xxxxx_pack_o  - original      travel times before packing
 xxxxx_pack_r  - reconstructed travel times after unpacking
 xxxxx_pack_d  - difference between original and reconstructed travel times

kmig - FIRST_TAB_QC
First travel time table to output qc files for in this job.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int >= 1

 Default = 1

kmig - ROOT_TAB_QC
File name for ray information.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 NONE means no file is created.

Help.Tip: Travel time table memory computation option.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_TABLE_MEM
Travel time table memory computation option.
 
 Default = TABLE_MEM_TO_USE
 Allowed = TABLES_IN_MEMORY Use TABLES_IN_MEMORY to compute number of tables.
 Allowed = TABLE_MEM_TO_USE Use TABLE_MEM_TO_USE to compute number of tables.

Help.Tip: Travel time table disk buffer computation option.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_TABLE_DISK
Travel time table disk buffer computation option.
 
 Default = TABLE_DISK_TO_USE
 Allowed = TABLES_ON_DISK Use TABLES_ON_DISK to compute number of tables.
 Allowed = TABLE_DISK_TO_USE Use TABLE_DISK_TO_USE to compute number of tables.

Help.Tip: Maximum number of travel time tables saved in memory.
Help.Text:
kmig - TABLES_IN_MEMORY
Maximum number of travel time tables saved in memory.
 
 Default = 8
 Allowed = int>= 1
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 Maximum number of travel time tables saved in memory.
 Increasing TABLES_IN_MEMORY decreases the amount of disk i/o  at the expense
 of increased memory usage.  The minimum values for TABLES_IN_MEMORY are
   TABLES_IN_MEMORY = 1 for TYPE_TABLE_CALC=VOFZ
   TABLES_IN_MEMORY >=2 for 2D poststack
   TABLES_IN_MEMORY >=4 for 2D prestack
   TABLES_IN_MEMORY >=4 for 3D poststack
   TABLES_IN_MEMORY >=8 for 3D prestack

Help.Tip: Maximum number of travel time tables saved in disk buffer.

kmig - TABLES_ON_DISK
Maximum number of travel time tables saved in disk buffer.
 
 Default = 8
 Allowed = int>= 1
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 Maximum number of travel time tables saved in memory.

Help.Tip: Unknown.
Help.Text:
kmig - TABLE_MEM_TO_USE
Unknown.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 Number of words of memory to use for travel time tables saved in memory.
 Increasing TABLE_MEM_TO_USE decreases the amount of disk i/o  at the expense
 of increased memory usage.  The minimum values for TABLE_MEM_TO_USE are

Help.Text:
kmig - AP_DEP_INIT
Minimum depth in travel time table.
 
 Default = -999 = compute from image range.
 Allowed = real
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 For depth migration units are velocity distance units.
 The travel time table is comupted on a coarse grid over the table  interval
 defined by AP_DEP_TOT, AP_DEP_INIT, AP_DEP_LAST and AP_DEP_INC

Help.Tip: Minimum X location for travel time tables.
Help.Text:
kmig - TABLE_X_INIT
Minimum X location for travel time tables.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 Units are defined by HDR_X.
 TABLE_X_TOT, TABLE_X_INIT, TABLE_X_LAST and TABLE_X_INC define
 the range of travel time tables. ! If TABLE_X_TOT <= 0 KMIG will
 compute and use the maximum X travel time table range from the
 other input parameters.
 Travel time tables are computed and saved on a coarse grid with
 spacing TABLE_X_INC between X locations. The travel time table
 which is actualy used is interpolated from the four surrounding
 tables computed on the coarse grid. The larger TABLE_X_INC gets
 the less CPU time and disk space is recquired at the cost of
 decreased accuracy.

Help.Tip: Minimum Y location for travel time tables.
Help.Text:
kmig - TABLE_Y_INIT
Minimum Y location for travel time tables.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Not used for time migration and DMO.

 Travel time tables are computed and saved on a coarse grid with

 which is actualy used is interpolated from the four surrounding

Help.Tip: Depth spacing within precomputed tables, includeing time tables.
Help.Text:
kmig - AP_DEP_INC
Depth spacing within precomputed tables, includeing time tables.
 
 Default = -1 = use 10 * DEP_INC
 Allowed = real
 KMIG precomputes a number of tables on a coarse vertical grid.
 AP_DEP_INC defines the vertical spacing within these tables.
 Needed values are computed from these tables via linear interpolation.
 This includes the vertical computational grid for imaging.
 Increasing AP_DEP_INC may reduce memory and improve CPU efficiency at the
 cost of reduced mapping accuracy.
 Units are velocity depth units.
 
 The travel time table is comupted on a coarse grid over the table interval
 defined by AP_DEP_TOT, AP_DEP_INIT, AP_DEP_LAST and AP_DEP_INC

Help.Tip: Default path_table list.
Help.Text:
kmig - FILENAME_OPERATION
Default path_table list.
 
 Default = USER
 Allowed = CLEAR  Clear the entries in PATH_TABLE.
 Allowed = USER   Allow manual entry in PATH_TABLE.
 Allowed = PATH_1 Create travel time table pathnames using the PATH_1 set.
 Allowed = PATH_2 Create travel time table pathnames using the PATH_2 set.
 Allowed = PATH_3 Create travel time table pathnames using the PATH_3 set.
 Allowed = PATH_4 Create travel time table pathnames using the PATH_4 set.
 Allowed = PATH_5 Create travel time table pathnames using the PATH_5 set.
 Allowed = PATH_6 Create travel time table pathnames using the PATH_6 set.
 
 If FILENAME_OPERATION = PATH_1, then 12 travel time table pathnames are
 created:  /ptmp/poeplx06/scratch/ through /ptmp/poeplx50/scratch/
 incrementing by 4 with the ROOT_TABLE value appended to each pathname.
 
 If FILENAME_OPERATION = PATH_2, then 12 travel time table pathnames are
 created:  /ptmp/poeplx08/scratch/ through /ptmp/poeplx52/scratch/
 incrementing by 4 with the ROOT_TABLE value appended to each pathname.
 
 If FILENAME_OPERATION = PATH_3, then 12 travel time table pathnames are
 created:  /ptmp/poeptt01/scratch/ through /ptmp/poeptt12/scratch/
 incrementing by 1 with the ROOT_TABLE value appended to each pathname.
 
 If FILENAME_OPERATION = PATH_4, then 12 travel time table pathnames are
 created:  /ptmp/poeptt13/scratch/ through /ptmp/poeptt24/scratch/
 incrementing by 1 with the ROOT_TABLE value appended to each pathname.
 
 If FILENAME_OPERATION = PATH_5, then 12 travel time table pathnames are
 created:  /ptmp/poeptt25/scratch/ through /ptmp/poeptt36/scratch/
 incrementing by 1 with the ROOT_TABLE value appended to each pathname.
 
 If FILENAME_OPERATION = PATH_6, then 12 travel time table pathnames are
 created:  /ptmp/poeptt37/scratch/ through /ptmp/poeptt48/scratch/
 incrementing by 1 with the ROOT_TABLE value appended to each pathname.
 
 If FILENAME_OPERATION = CLEAR, then clear the entries in PATH_TABLE.
 
 If FILENAME_OPERATION = USER, then allow manual entry in PATH_TABLE.

Help.Tip: Root name of travel time table file.
Help.Text:
kmig - ROOT_TABLE
Root name of travel time table file.
 
 Default = KMIG.table
 Allowed = character
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 If ROOT_TABLE is defined KMIG will construct the travelt time table file
 name by appending ROOT_TABLE to to the prefix names in PATH_TABLE.

Help.Tip: Name of travel time table file.
Help.Text:
kmig - PATH_TABLE
Name of travel time table file.
 
 Default = KMIG.table
 Allowed = character
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 If the file name starts with a valid directory such as /tmp/ptmp/hanson
 the file is written to that directory and becomes a premanent file.
 If this is ommitted the file is temporary and is not saved after the job
 If this file does not exist KMIG will create it and write tables to it.
 If this file already exists KMIG will use the tables already in the file.
 If this file already exists make sure that it was created using the same
 model file name and travel time table setup parameters.
 File are written to the various file names in a round robin fashion.

kmig - OPT_DATUM
Whether datum parameters are set.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES Datum parameters are enabled.
 Allowed = NO  Datum parameters are disabled.

kmig - OPT_SRC_DATUM
Whether to use constant or spatialy varying SRC_DATUM.

kmig - CONST_SRC_DATUM
Source datum file.

 Allowed = character

 If CONST_SRC_DATUM is other than NONE the Z values in it will be used as the

 It will be used for setting the aliasing condition.

Receiver constant datum level depth.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 If the receiver elevations vary, they should be in an ascci data file
 - CONST_SRC_DATUM is other than NONE the Z values in it will be used as the
 receiver datum level.
 CONST_REC_DATUM should then be set to an average receiver depth.
 It will be used for setting the aliasing condition.

src_datum path name.

Help.Tip: Raytrace time increment option.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_RAY_INC
Raytrace time increment option.
 
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 Default = CONSTANT  use constant.
 Allowed = READ      read from file
 Allowed = WRITE     compute and write to file
 Allowed = COMPUTE   compute only.
 
 During raytracing KMIG shoots rays in a series of stages.
 The first two stages are the micro step and micro step.
 Each ray is handled separately during the micro and macro stages.
 
 Each macro step consists of several micro steps.
 
 During a single micro step the ray position and ray parameter is
 extrapolated out a micro time step distance from intial ray location
 using the ray parameter and velocity at the ray location at the start
 of the micro step.
 
 If OPT_RAY_INC = CONSTANT the value of the micro ray step length
 is kept constant throughout the velocity model and for all rays.
 
 If OPT_RAY_INC is not CONSTANT the value of the micro ray step length
 is varies throughout the velocity model with a resultant efficiency
 improvement.
 
 The size of the variable ray time step length is controled by parameter
 RAY_TIM_ACCURACY.  Decreasing RAY_TIM_ACCURACY will cause KMIG to
 take smaller ray time steps when the velocity field varies rapidly.
 
 If OPT_RAY_INC = READ the value of the variable ray time step length
 read from a precomputed data file stored in the file PATH_RAY_INC
 at the model input stage,
 
 If OPT_RAY_INC = COMPUTE or WRITE the value of the variable ray time
 step length is precomputed just before the first travel time table
 is computed.
 
 If OPT_RAY_INC = WRITE the value of the variable ray time
 is written to the file PATH_RAY_INC for later reuse.
 
 The algorithm for computing the variable ray time step length follows:
 
 RAY_TIM_INC is the minimum micro ray step in seconds.
 RAY_MICRO_RATIO is the nominal number of ray micro steps per macro time step.
 
 For each input velocity node KMIG shoots a series of isotropic test rays
 at a variety of angles with different micro ray step lengths of
 I * RAY_TIM_INC where I varies from 1 to RAY_MICRO_RATIO.
 
 It then computes RAY_TIM_DIFFERENCE (I) = the time distance between the
 endpoints of of the ray shot with a ray time step length of
 I * RAY_TIM_INC .
 
 KMIG looks through all the test rays and finds the largest I index
 for which the maximum value of RAY_TIM_DIFFERENC(I) <= RAY_TIM_ACCURACY.
 
 Note:
 
 The I = 1 ray is considered to be the most accurate because it samples
 the field velocity most finely and is the default setting for the ray time
 step length if OPT_RAY_INC = CONSTANT.
 
 The I = RAY_MICRO_RATIO ray is considered to be the least accurate because
 it samples the field velocity most coarsely.

Help.Tip: Ray inc path name.
Help.Text:
kmig - SELECT_PATH_RAY_INC
Ray inc path name.

Help.Tip: Pathname of ray inc file.
Help.Text:
kmig - PATH_RAY_INC
Pathname of ray inc file.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character

Help.Tip: Ray selection type.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_RAY
Ray selection type.
 
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 Default = SHORTEST  3--shortest raypath
 Allowed = ENERGETIC 1--most energetic  - will greatly increase cpu time.
 Allowed = FIRST     2--first arrival
 Allowed = SHORTEST  3--shortest raypath
 Allowed = VELOCITY  4--smallest maximum velocity
 Allowed = LAST      5--longest time
 Allowed = LONGEST   6--longest raypath

Help.Tip: Raytrace coefficient interpolation.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_RAY_GRAD
Raytrace coefficient interpolation.
 
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 Default = VELOCITY  interpolate velocity.
 Allowed = SLOWNESS  interpolate slowness.
 
 If OPT_RAY_GRAD = VELOCITY all ray traceing velocity gradient computations
 assume linear velocity between model x,y,z nodes.
 
 This will produce slightly different same travel times for velocity models
 that repesent the same velocity variation but have different
 sampling characteristics.
 
 This is the original KMIG assumption for ray tracing and is not consistent
 with other travel time table computation methods.
 
 If OPT_RAY_GRAD = SLOWNESS all ray traceing velocity gradient computations
 assume linear slowness between model x,y,z nodes.
 
 This is the original KMIG assumption regarding velocity variation and is
 consistent with other travel time table computation methods.
 
 This will produce the same travel times for velocity models
 that repesent the same velocity variation but have different
 sampling characteristics.
 
 Note, amplitude computations which depend upon the second derivitive of the
 velocity with respect to x,y,z are still done assuming linear velocity
 variations.

Help.Tip: Raytrace step correction.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_RAY_STEP
Raytrace step correction.
 
 Default = CONSTANT  Do not correct for velocity variation over ray step.
 Allowed = GRADIENT  Do correct for velocity variation over ray step.
 
 If OPT_RAY_STEP = CONSTANT all ray time to distance computations
 assume constant velocity at the ray start point.
 This is the original method used by KMIG for computing ray step lengths.
 
 If OPT_RAY_STEP = GRADIENT all ray time to distance computations
 assume linear velocity between model x,y,z nodes.
 This corrects for a slight variation in the computed travel times
 as a function of the ray step length.

Help.Tip: Raytrace ray bending option.
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_RAY_BEND
Raytrace ray bending option.
 
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 Default = START   Use the velocity gradient at the start of the ray step.
 Allowed = END     Use the velocity gradient at the end of the ray step.
 Allowed = AVERAGE Use the average velocity gradient overf the ray step.
 
 If OPT_RAY_BEND = START all ray bending computations
 use the velocity gradient at the start of the ray step.
 This is the original method use dby KMIG for computing ray bending.
 
 If OPT_RAY_BEND = END all ray bending computations
 use the velocity gradient at the end of the ray step.
 
 If OPT_RAY_BEND = AVERAGE all ray bending computations
 use the velocity gradient average at the start and end of the ray step.
 This is probably the most correct method for computing ray bending.

Help.Tip: Maximum numner of rays to traces at any time step.
Help.Text:
kmig - RAY_MAX_NUMBER
Maximum numner of rays to traces at any time step.
 
 Default = 30001
 Allowed = int > 0
 Not used for time migration and DMO.

Help.Tip: Ray time accuracy limit in seconds.
Help.Text:
kmig - RAY_TIM_ACCURACY
Ray time accuracy limit in seconds.
 
 Default = .001
 Allowed = 0 <= real
 Ray time accuracy limit for variable ray step length ray tracing.
 During raytracing KMIG shoots rays in a series of stages.
 The first two stages are the micro step and micro step.
 Each ray is handled separately during the micro and macro stages.
 
 Each macro step consists of several micro steps.
 
 During a single micro step the ray position and ray parameter is
 extrapolated out a micro time step distance from intial ray location

 If OPT_RAY_INC = CONSTANT the value of the micro ray step length
