 If OPT_RAY_INC is not CONSTANT the value of the micro ray step length
 is varies throughout the velocity model with a resultant efficiency
 improvement.
 
 The size of the variable ray time step length is controled by parameter
 RAY_TIM_ACCURACY.  Decreasing RAY_TIM_ACCURACY will cause KMIG to
 take smaller ray time steps when the velocity field varies rapidly.
 
 If OPT_RAY_INC = READ the value of the variable ray time step length
 read from a precomputed data file stored in the file PATH_RAY_INC
 at the model input stage,
 
 If OPT_RAY_INC = COMPUTE or WRITE the value of the variable ray time
 step length is precomputed just before the first travel time table
 is computed.
 
 If OPT_RAY_INC = WRITE the value of the variable ray time
 is written to the file PATH_RAY_INC for later reuse.
 
 The algorithm for computing the variable ray time step length follows:
 
 RAY_TIM_INC is the minimum micro ray step in seconds.
 RAY_MICRO_RATIO is the nominal number of ray micro steps per macro time step.
 
 For each input velocity node KMIG shoots a series of isotropic test rays
 at a variety of angles with different micro ray step lengths of
 I * RAY_TIM_INC where I varies from 1 to RAY_MICRO_RATIO.
 
 It then computes RAY_TIM_DIFFERENCE (I) = the time distance between the
 endpoints of of the ray shot with a ray time step length of
 I * RAY_TIM_INC .
 
 KMIG looks through all the test rays and finds the largest I index
 for which the maximum value of RAY_TIM_DIFFERENC(I) <= RAY_TIM_ACCURACY.
 
 Note:
 
 The I = 1 ray is considered to be the most accurate because it samples
 the field velocity most finely and is the default setting for the ray time
 step length if OPT_RAY_INC = CONSTANT.
 
 The I = RAY_MICRO_RATIO ray is considered to be the least accurate because
 it samples the field velocity most coarsely.

Help.Tip: Ray interpolation factor.
Help.Text:
kmig - RAY_INTERPOLATION
Ray interpolation factor.
 
 Default = 10
 Allowed = int > 0
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 New rays are interpolated between old rays every RAY_INTERPOLATION macro
 time steps.  Making this larger will reduce the CPU requirements and accuracy.

Help.Tip: Number of ray micro time steps in a macro time step.
Help.Text:
kmig - RAY_MICRO_RATIO
Number of ray micro time steps in a macro time step.
 
 Default = 5
 Allowed = int > 0
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 Ray information is extrapolated in micro time step intervals.
 Rays are interpolated to the table every RAY_MICRO_RATIO micro time steps.
 When using variable ray time step lengths this is a upper limit.

Help.Tip: Ray stopping angle in degrees.
Help.Text:
kmig - RAY_MAX_ANGLE
Ray stopping angle in degrees.
 
 Default = 135.
 Allowed = 0 <= real <=180
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 Maximum ray turning angle from the Z axis in degrees.
 Rays that turn beyond this angle are stopped. Use 90. or greater.

Help.Tip: Ray tube to grid node interpolation option
Help.Text:
kmig - OPT_RAY_FILL
Ray tube to grid node interpolation option
 
 Default = OLD
 Allowed = OLD     The original average surrounding time algorithm.
 Allowed = AVERAGE The revised  average surrounding time algorithm.
 Allowed = EIKONAL Crude EIKONAL solution.

Help.Tip: Ray tube fill scale factor.
Help.Text:
kmig - SCALE_RAY_FILL
Ray tube fill scale factor.
 
 Default = 2.
 Allowed = real
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 If any ray tube side dimension exceeds SCALE_RAY_FILL * TABLE_COMP_INC
 the ray tube segment will not be used to fill in table nodes.

Help.Tip: Maximum number of micro ray time steps.
Help.Text:
kmig - RAY_TIM_TOT
Maximum number of micro ray time steps.
 
 Default = NDPT/5
 Allowed = real > 0.
 Not used for time migration and DMO.

Help.Tip: Initial number of rays for the angle measured from the z axis.
Help.Text:
kmig - RAY_ANG1_TOT
Initial number of rays for the angle measured from the z axis.
 
 Default = 46
 Allowed = int > 0
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 If RAY_ANG1 < 0 the ANG1 coefficients will be set to the defaults
 For DIMENSON = 2D :
                     RAY_ANG1_TOT  = 91
                     RAY_ANG1_INIT = -90.
                     RAY_ANG1_LAST = +90.
                     RAY_ANG1_INC  = 2.
 For DIMENSON = 3D :
                     RAY_ANG1_TOT  = 46
                     RAY_ANG1_INIT = 0.
                     RAY_ANG1_LAST = +90.
                     RAY_ANG1_INC  = 2.

Help.Tip: Initial number of rays for the angle measured around the z axis.
Help.Text:
kmig - RAY_ANG2_TOT
Initial number of rays for the angle measured around the z axis.
 
 Default = 181
 Allowed = int > 0
 Not used for time migration and DMO.

Help.Tip: Initial ray time value in seconds.
Help.Text:
kmig - RAY_TIM_INIT
Initial ray time value in seconds.
 
 Default = TSTRT
 Allowed = real >= 0
 This should be a small non zero number.
 Not used for time migration and DMO.

Help.Tip: Minimum ray angle for the angle measured from the z axis.
Help.Text:
kmig - RAY_ANG1_INIT
Minimum ray angle for the angle measured from the z axis.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = 0 <= real <= 360.
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 For DIMENSON = 2D :
                     RAY_ANG1_TOT  = 91
                     RAY_ANG1_INIT = -90.
                     RAY_ANG1_LAST = +90.
                     RAY_ANG1_INC  = 2.
 For DIMENSON = 3D :
                     RAY_ANG1_TOT  = 46
                     RAY_ANG1_INIT = 0.
                     RAY_ANG1_LAST = +90.
                     RAY_ANG1_INC  = 2.

Help.Tip: Minimum ray angle for the angle measured around the z axis.
Help.Text:
kmig - RAY_ANG2_INIT
Minimum ray angle for the angle measured around the z axis.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = 0 <= real <= 360.
 Not used for time migration and DMO.

Help.Tip: Maximum ray time value in seconds.
Help.Text:
kmig - RAY_TIM_LAST
Maximum ray time value in seconds.
 
 Default = (NDPT-1)*DT+TSTRT
 Allowed = real > RAY_TIM_INIT
 Not used for time migration and DMO.

Help.Tip: Maximum ray angle for the angle measured from the z axis.
Help.Text:
kmig - RAY_ANG1_LAST
Maximum ray angle for the angle measured from the z axis.
 
 Default = 90
 Allowed = 0 <= real <= 360.
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 For DIMENSON = 2D :
                     RAY_ANG1_TOT  = 91
                     RAY_ANG1_INIT = -90.
                     RAY_ANG1_LAST = +90.
                     RAY_ANG1_INC  = 2.
 For DIMENSON = 3D :
                     RAY_ANG1_TOT  = 46
                     RAY_ANG1_INIT = 0.
                     RAY_ANG1_LAST = +90.
                     RAY_ANG1_INC  = 2.

Help.Tip: Maximum ray angle for the angle measured around the z axis.
Help.Text:
kmig - RAY_ANG2_LAST
Maximum ray angle for the angle measured around the z axis.
 
 Default = 360
 Allowed = 0 <= real <= 360.
 Not used for time migration and DMO.

Help.Tip: Time length of micro ray step in seconds.
Help.Text:
kmig - RAY_TIM_INC
Time length of micro ray step in seconds.
 
 Default = 5*DT
 Allowed = real
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 When using variable ray time step lengths this is a lower limit.

Help.Tip: Ray angle increment for the angle measured from the z axis.
Help.Text:
kmig - RAY_ANG1_INC
Ray angle increment for the angle measured from the z axis.
 
 Default = 2
 Allowed = 0 <= real <= 360.
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 For DIMENSON = 2D :
                     RAY_ANG1_TOT  = 91
                     RAY_ANG1_INIT = -90.
                     RAY_ANG1_LAST = +90.
                     RAY_ANG1_INC  = 2.
 For DIMENSON = 3D :
                     RAY_ANG1_TOT  = 46
                     RAY_ANG1_INIT = 0.
                     RAY_ANG1_LAST = +90.
                     RAY_ANG1_INC  = 2.

Help.Tip: Ray angle increment for the angle measured around the z axis.
Help.Text:
kmig - RAY_ANG2_INC
Ray angle increment for the angle measured around the z axis.
 
 Default = 2
 Allowed = real
 Not used for time migration and DMO.

Help.Tip: Button that removes this process parameter screen.
Help.Text:
kmig - CLOSE
Button that removes this process parameter screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Appears only on the view-only process parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.

kmig - OK
Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values, runs the parameter traps and removes
 the parameter screen.

kmig - APPLY
Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
 
 Default =

 Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps but does
 not remove the parameter screen.

kmig - CANCEL
Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =

Help.Tip: Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
Help.Text:
kmig - RESET
Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that sets the parameters back to their values when the screen appeared
 or to their last applied value.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.

kmig - PROCESSLISTLEFT
Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the previous process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.

kmig - PROCESSLIST
Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Menu that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the

kmig - PROCESSLISTRIGHT
Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
 
 Default =

 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the

Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
 
 Default =

<html><head><base href=file:///usr/app/vendors/int/Conoco/xml/help/> <pre>------------------------------------------------------------------------------ C P S P R O C E S S
Name : KMIG Category : Migrations Written : 2000-05-01 by: Douglas Hanson Revised : 2006-08-29 by: Douglas Hanson Add TYPE_TABLE_CALC=RAYSHVTI. Maturity : production Purpose : Kirchhoff DMO and time and depth migrations Portability: No known limitations. Parallel : Yes.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------ ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ GENERAL DESCRIPTION
Time and depth processing.
KMIG can conduct either time or depth migration as well as DMO. For time migration and DMO all parameters which deal with the vertical grid will be expressed in time units. Most of these parameters include the term TIME in their names. For depth migration all parameters which deal with the vertical grid will be expressed in depth units. Most of these parameters include the term DEPTH in their names.
Input and Output Trace Coordinates and header words. Input parameters HDR_X and HDR_Y specify the X and Y header words used to define the coordinates for input traces and for the output image grid. These should be 7,8 or 8,7 or 17,18 or 18,17 only.
The input velocity file, PATH_VEL, must use these same X and Y header words. usually header words. Header words 7, 8 are midpoint in grid units and header words 17, 18 are midpoint in distance units.
The input trace X and Y midpoints are determined from header words HDR_X and HDR_Y respectively. The input trace offset is determined by header word 6.
If HDR_X and HDR_Y are 7,8 or 8,7, input trace azimuth is computed from the source and receiver grid position header words 33, 34, 35 and 36.
If HDR_X and HDR_Y are 17,18 or 18,17, input trace azimuth is computed from the source and receiver distance position header words 11, 12, 14 and 15.
The source and receiver positions are computed from the azimuth defined by parameter AZIMUTH and the absolute offset of the input data. and is given by x offset = absolute offset * cosine ( azimuth ) y offset = absolute offset * sine ( azimuth ) a positive x offset has the source x location greater than the x receiver location.
Input trace source and receiver positions are computed from the midpoint, offset and azimuth. Input trace midpoints need not fall exactly on the specified output trace locations.
KMIG will print a warning the first 10 times it detects a difference between the offset determined from the original input source and receiver separation as defined by the original input values of the source receiver header words and the offset in header word 6. KMIG will migrate such traces using the header word 6 offset.
KMIG sets the output header words HDR_X and HDR_Y to that defined by the output trace grid and output header word 6 to the output offset value. KMIG sets the adjoint to header words HDR_X and HDR_Y (7,17) and (8,18) using the CPS grid transform which must be properly defined.
Output image traces are labeled in header word 24 with the index number of the FCTR_VEL array corresponding to that image, from 1 to the total number of multipliers, and in header word 63 with the corresponding velocity multiplier. Sort order of output traces from fastest to slowest is: FCTR_VEL value, HDR_Y, HDR_Y and offset. It may be necessary to sort output traces to the desired order.
With the exception of the above mentioned header words, KMIG will set the output traces header words to those of the input trace which contributed to that output trace and whose midpoint was closest to that output trace position. Note this currently includes the mute header words.
offset Parameters
The KMIG offset parameters, OFF_TOT, OFF_INIT, OFF_LAST and OFF_INC define a set of offset bins. Each KMIG output image is associated with an offset bin. KMIG migrates each offset bin separately, that is, only input traces with header word 6 within a particular offset bin contribute to the output image associated with that offset bin. Output images are produced only for those offset bins that are occupied by input traces.
However, if ONE_IMAGE = YES, then only one offset bin is used as set by the offset of the first input trace.
When KMIG senses that the offset of a new input trace falls into a new output offset bin it will output the contents of the current image and start a new image. This makes it imperative that the input data be sorted to common offset bins defined by the output offset grid prior to imaging. If you entered CMP sorted data with ONE_IMAGE = NO KMIG could output an entire image volume for every input trace. For 3D work usually one offset at a time is migrated. For 2D work the entire line is usually migrated at once.
Amplitude treatment
KMIG corrects for obliquity effects to the input trace amplitudes during the imaging process. KMIG also allows a fold of stack correction to the output trace amplitudes. No correction is made for geometric divergence.
Because the migration aperture and fresnel zone generally increase with time, the number of input trace samples summed into any given output trace increases significantly with output time. This often goes a long ways towards correcting for geometric divergence. I recommend testing various premigration amplitude corrections before final imaging.
Impulse response and other tests.
A number of different imaging experiments can be used to evaluate the velocity field and imaging parameters and imaging costs.
These include:
Impulse response tests.
An impulse response test is where one or a few input traces are imaged to an output volume. These are used for many purposes and are the single most useful and economical tool for parameter estimation. These are also known as broadcast pattern tests.
Line tests.
A line test is when a single X or Y line of input data is imaged to the corresponding output X or Y image line. These are often used to evaluate the migration velocity field, especialy if several offset volumes are imaged separtely and the separate common offset images are sorted to common image point gathers (CIPs) where velocity errors appear similar to velocity errors in moveout corrected CMPs.
Swath tests.
A swath test is where a swath of input data is imaged to a single X or Y in 3D. The input swath is usually the length of the output X or Y and spans an apertures' width to either side. These represent a full input volume image of the output X or Y and indicate the quality of the final image.
Patch tests.
A patch test is where an entire 3D input volume is imaged to a patch of Xs and Ys in 3D which represents perhaps 10 percent of the entire output volume. This yields the most accurate estimate of image quality and CPU cost of the full imaging experiment.
Timing tests.
A timing test involves imaging a coarsely sampled subset of an input volume to a full output volume in order to get CPU and cost estimates. Input traces near the edge of the output volume will sum into fewer output traces and take less CPU time to image than input traces in the middle of the output volume. To ensure an accurate estimate of the full imaging cost the input traces should be evenly spaced over the full input volume in both the X and Y directions. I recommend imaging using perhaps 11 Ys each with 100 - 1000 input traces. For prestack imaging you may need to do this for several offsets, perhaps near, mid, far. The near offsets tend to be most expensive with the far offsets costing perhaps 60 percent of the near. However, this will vary with your choice of apertures.
Imaging costs.
Because the time migration aperture tends to increase with time you can expect the migration cost to increase significantly when you increase the aperture or maximum output time. For a constant dip the aperture volume and CPU cost increase by the cube of the maximum output time. For this reason you will often select a maximum aperture which crops the steeper dips at large output times. When you reach this maximum aperture limit the increase of CPU will be linear with respect to the additional output time.
KMIG will print a number of statistics at the end of output for each offset volume that is imaged. This will occur under the title
KMIG IMAGING STATISTICS
Some of the statistics such as time required to output the final volume are not dependant upon the number of input traces. Others such as data input, output trace swapping, input trace filtering and input to output trace mapping will be proportional to the number of input traces. These statistics are very useful in estimating project costs.
Aperture parameters.
Aperture parameters in KMIG expect the "half-aperture," where half-aperture is the distance an input trace can migrate in one direction, NOT the total range. If the full aperture is 2000 m, a trace can migrate no more than 1000m in one direction and 1000m in the opposite direction and the half-aperture is 1000m.
Migration Velocity File
The migration velocity file specified in PATH_VEL must use the same header words as coordinates as the grid coordinates specified for output trace locations (HDR_X and HDR_Y).
Before Stack vs. After Stack Migration
For after stack (zero-offset) migration using KMIG the offset header word of input traces should be set to zero and you should set ONE_IMAGE = YES, OFF_TOT = 1 and OFF_INIT = 0.0. For before stack migration, the offset parameters should be set to define the desired offset bins.
Time migration theory.
The following describes the map between input and output time for isotropic and anisotropic time migration. Isotropic time migration is the special case of anisotropic time migration with VEL_ETA=0., A0=1.
For forward time migration: TX = input time, TZ = output time. For inverse time migration: TZ = input time, TX = output time.
Note for inverse time migration only VEL_ETA = 0 currently works.
Prestack Time Migration for Anisotropic Media Gregory D. Lazear Research Report 2558-1-95 April 1995
Equations 12 and 13 yield:
One way travel times from a surface location to an image location are computed via the formulae:
Isotropic
Tx = sqrt{ (Tz**2 + x**2 / Vnmo**2) }
Anisotropic
Tx = sqrt{ (Tz**2 + x**2 / Vnmo**2) * ((Tz**2 + a0 * x**2 / Vnmo**2) / (Tz**2 + x**2 / Vnmo**2 ))}
where Tx = the travel time from source to image location Tz = the vertical travel time x = horizontal distance from source to image location Vnmo = NMO velocity A0 = 1 / (1. + 2. * VEL_ETA) VEL_ETA = Anisotropic coefficient = (Vhorizontal**2 - Vnmo**2 ) / (2. * Vnmo**2 )
The input velocity is assumed to be a stacking velocity and will be converted to an NMO velocity via the relationship
Vnmo**4 * Tz**2 + Vnmo**2 * (OFF**2 - Vstk**2 * Tz**2 * A1) - OFF**2 * Vstk**2 * A2 = 0
or
Vnmo = sqrt{(-b + sqrt ( b**2 - 4. * a * c)) / (2. * a))}
Where a = Tz**2 b = OFF**2 - Vstk**2 * Tz**2 c = - OFF**2 / Vstk**2 * A2 Vstk = Stacking velocity OFF = offset used for computing Vstk A1 = A0**2 A2 = (1. + A1) / A1
DMO theory
The forward and inverse DMO theory is based ON:
Data Reconstruction and Reflectivity Mapping in 3 Dimensions Robert H. Stolt Research Report 2558-1-98, October 1998
For forward DMO the output offset h_dmo, is 0. and equation 75 is :
data_out ( x_out, y_out, h_dmo, t_dmo ) = & integral dx_dmo * f_dmo(+45) 1. / sqrt ( 2 * pi ) / h_off * ( 1. + x_dmo**2 / h_off**2 ) / ( 1. - x_dmo**2 / h_off**2 ) ** 2 * t_off / sqrt ( t_dmo ) * data_inp ( x_inp, y_inp, h_off, t_off )
using t_off = t_dmo * sqrt ( 1. - x_dmo**2 / h_off**2 ) t_off / sqrt ( t_dmo ) = sqrt ( t_dmo ) * ( 1. - x_dmo**2 / h_off**2 ) ** 5
Equation 75 reduces to :
data_out ( x_out, y_out, h_dmo, t_dmo ) = & integral dx_dmo * f_dmo(+45) 1. / sqrt ( 2 * pi ) / h_off * ( 1. + x_dmo**2 / h_off**2 ) / ( 1. - x_dmo**2 / h_off**2 ) ** 1.5 * sqrt ( t_dmo ) * data_inp ( x_inp, y_inp, h_off, t_off )
The time map, equation 76, is:
t_off = t_dmo * sqrt ( - x_dmo**2 / h_off**2 )
For inverse DMO the input offset h_dmo, is 0. and equation 80 is :
data_out ( x_out, y_out, h_off, t_off ) = & integral dx_dmo * f_dmo(-45) * 1. / sqrt ( 2 * pi ) / h_off / ( 1. - x_dmo**2 / h_off**2 ) t_dmo / sqrt ( t_off ) * data_inp ( x_inp, y_inp, h_dmo, t_dmo )
using t_dmo = t_off / sqrt ( 1. - x_dmo**2 / h_off**2 ) t_dmo / sqrt ( t_off ) = sqrt ( t_off ) / ( 1. - x_dmo**2 / h_off**2 ) ** .5
Equation 80 reduces to :
data_out ( x_out, y_out, h_off, t_off ) = & integral dx_dmo * f_dmo(-45) * 1. / sqrt ( 2 * pi ) / h_off / ( 1. - x_dmo**2 / h_off**2 ) ** 1.5 * sqrt ( t_off ) * data_inp ( x_inp, y_inp, h_dmo, t_dmo )
for forward dmo rt_inp = t_off and rt_out = t_dmo for inverse dmo rt_inp = t_dmo and rt_out = t_off ra_map(it_map) = ra_dmo * sqrt ( t_off ) ra_map(it_map) = ra_dmo * sqrt ( t5_tmp )
The time map, equation 76, is:
t_dmo = t_off / sqrt ( 1. - x_dmo**2 / h_off**2 )
The aperture defined by equation 77, is:
x_dmo < h_off * b_dmo / sqrt ( 1.+b_dmo**2 )
where
f_dmo(+45) is a +45 degree phase shift frequency filter. f_dmo(-45) is a -45 degree phase shift frequency filter. t_dmo = zero offset time t_off = non zero offset time t_out = ouptut time h_off = non zero half offset x_dmo = distance between input and output midpoints b_dmo = h_off * s_dmo / (t_off * v_dmo * .5) s_dmo = sine(maximum dip in the data) = 1. for this implementation. v_dmo = dmo velocity
The aperture for 3D is defined by the grid of points falling to either side of the line from the source to the receiver.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------- ADVICE FOR USERS
Parameter descriptions
Parameter DIMENSION determines the dimensionality of the KMIG computation. 2D , M2D and 3D are Valid
If DIMENSION = 2D, KMIG uses a 2D migration or DMO algorithm. However the user may still use multiple input and output Ys. Any given input Y will only contribute to only those output Ys which fall within the Y aperture. This allows the user to conduct a number of 2D migrations in a single job.
Parameter MIG_TYPE determines what type of image mapping KMIG uses, TIM_MIG, DEP_MIG, and DMO are valid.
If MIG_TYPE = TIM_MIG KMIG uses forward or inverse time migration. If MIG_TYPE = DEP_MIG KMIG uses forward depth migration. If MIG_TYPE = DMO KMIG uses forward or inverse DMO.
Parameter OPT_DIR determines whether KMIG does a forward or inverse time map. FORWARD and INVERSE are valid.
If OPT_DIR = FORWARD KMIG uses forward time or depth migration or DMO.
If OPT_DIR = INVERSE KMIG uses inverse time migration or DMO.
Constucting a subset of the image via BASIC_IMAGE_SET and ACTIVE_IMAGE_SET modifiers.
The KMIG output image traces fall on a 2 D rectangular defined by parameters: X_TOT, X_INIT, X_FIRST, X_INC and Y_TOT, Y_INIT, Y_FIRST, Y_INC This set of image traces is referred to as the BASIC_IMAGE_SET.
By default KMIG will image into every one of the BASIC_IMAGE_SET traces which has a contribution from an input trace. However the user can exclude some of those BASIC_IMAGE_SET traces from the summation process in order to increase efficiency. This might be to exclude a portion of the BASIC_IMAGE_SET which does not have corresponding input bins, to form multiple coarse rectangular grids for velocity analysis or to form a crooked line output. The image traces from the BASIC_IMAGE_SET which are actually included in the imaging process is referred to as the ACTIVE_IMAGE_SET.
The traces of the BASIC_IMAGE_SET included in the ACTIVE_IMAGE_SET can be controlled by the following parameters:
Parameter OPT_SPARSE enables or disables parameters X_POLY, Y_POLY, ID_POLY define a set of closed polygons. SP_X_TOT, SP_X_INIT, SP_X_LAST, SP_X_INC SP_Y_TOT, SP_Y_INIT, SP_Y_LAST, SP_Y_INC
If OPT_SPARSE is YES the user will have acess to these parameters and they will modify the image volume. If OPT_SPARSE is NO the user will not have acess to these parameters and they will not modify the image volume. Note KMIG will not change the values of these parameters that may have been set at an earlier time when OPT_SPARSE=YES, but whatever their value, they will not modify the traces in the ACTIVE_IMAGE_SET.
Parameters X_POLY, Y_POLY, ID_POLY define a set of closed polygons. If these parameters are defined, only image nodes within these polygons are included in the ACTIVE_IMAGE_SET. Image nodes which fall directly on a polygon border are considered inside the polygon. The default for these parameters will include the entire BASIC_IMAGE_SET.
Parameters SP_X_TOT, SP_X_INIT, SP_X_LAST, SP_X_INC SP_Y_TOT, SP_Y_INIT, SP_Y_LAST, SP_Y_INC define a set of coarse grids.
If these parameters are defined, only image nodes included in one or the other of these two grids are included in the ACTIVE_IMAGE_SET. The default for these parameters will include the entire BASIC_IMAGE_SET. To use these parameters you must define both coarse grids. If you want only a single coarse grid you can do that more effectively by defining the BASIC_IMAGE_SET grid appropriately. Note also that these coarse grid nodes must fall on the nodes in the BASIC_IMAGE_SET.
Parameter PATH_POLY is an ascii file containing a list of image node locations. If PATH_POLY is defined, only image nodes included in this list are included in the ACTIVE_IMAGE_SET. To be included in the ACTIVE_IMAGE_SET the image node locations from PATH_POLY must fall directly on the BASIC_IMAGE_SET node locations. The default for PATH_POLY , "NONE", will include the entire BASIC_IMAGE_SET.
The format of the PATH_POLY file is: card 1 = X_FIL, Y_FIL, N_XY_POS cards 2:N_XY_POS+1 = X_POS, Y_POS where X_FIL = X header word for PATH_POLY Y_FIL = Y header word for PATH_POLY N_XY_POS = number of X, Y node location pairs. X_POS = X position Y_POS = Y position
note the PATH_POLY file X and cross line header words must be the same pair as HDR_X and HDR_Y. That is: X_FIL = HDR_X, Y_FIL = HDR_Y or Y_FIL = HDR_X, X_FIL = HDR_Y
Note each of these BASIC_IMAGE_SET modifiers acts in addition to the other modifiers. Hence you can define a closed polygon and/or a double coarse grid and/or arbitryary trace locations. For a trace to be include in the ACTIVE_IMAGE_SET it must satisfy all defined conditons. If one of the above modifiers is not defined it will have no effect on which traces of the BASIC_IMAGE_SET are included in the ACTIVE_IMAGE_SET.
The order of the output traces is not affected by which of these modifiers you select. Hence you will need to sort and select the data appropriately to separate the image traces from different coarse grids. The subset of traces from the BASIC_IMAGE_SET which are output by KMIG is controlled by paramter ALL_OUT as described below.
Parameter ALL_OUT determines which of the defined image traces in the BASIC_IMAGE_SET which will actually be output by KMIG. YES, NO, POLY_YES, and POLY_NO are valid.
If ALL_OUT = YES KMIG will output all image traces in the BASIC_IMAGE_SET defined by the X and Y output grids. This is required if you want to look at an impulse response for one or a few input traces.
If ALL_OUT = NO KMIG will output only those image traces in the BASIC_IMAGE_SET defined by the X and Y output grids which have had an input trace midpoint in them.
If ALL_OUT = POLY_YES KMIG will output all image traces in the ACTIVE_IMAGE_SET defined by the X and Y output grids and modified by the BASIC_IMAGE_SET modifers.
If ALL_OUT = POLY_NO KMIG will output only those image traces in the ACTIVE_IMAGE_SET defined by the X and Y output grids and modified by the BASIC_IMAGE_SET modifers, which have had an input trace midpoint in them.
Parameter ONE_IMAGE determines how KMIG will separate the output image traces when it senses that there has been a change in offset in the input traces. YES and NO are valid.
If ONE_IMAGE = YES KMIG will create a single output image for all offset groups.
If ONE_IMAGE = NO KMIG will create a different output image for each offset group it sees. It is imperative that the input data be correctly sorted into common offset groups in this case. Otherwise a new output volume will be constructed each time the input traces changes output offset bins.
Parameter OPT_OUTPUT defines the type of parameter that KMIG outputs. IMAGE, VELOCITY, TIME, AMP and ALIAS are valid.
IMAGE Output migration image. VELOCITY Output migration velocity. TIME Output migration two-way travel time. AMP Output migration amplitude. ALIAS Output migraiton anti aliasing coefficient.
Normally you want KMIG to construct the migration or DMO image from summation of all input traces. For this you would choose OPT_OUTPUT = IMAGE for the migration or DMO image. However you may want to look at one of the computed coefficients that KMIG uses during the migration process, such as VELOCITY, TIME, AMPlitude or ALIAS. In that case you should run KMIG using a single input trace and ALL_OUT = YES. Then KMIG will output the traces for the defined output grid with the trace amplitudes being the defined parameter within the migration aperture and zero elsewhere. If you want a parameter such as the velocity everywhere within your defined output grid, make sure you aperture parameters are large enough to span the entire output grid.
Parameters PAR_GROUPS and DIV_TYPE are for parallel processing
PAR_GROUPS - Number of parallel groups tp use
KMIG will break the job processors into PAR_GROUPS groups. Each group will image a subset of the input traces and construct an image indiependantly from th eother groups. at the end of processing the separate images will be summed to gether by KMIG and the result output on all pes. It is strongly reccommended that you the number of processors, NUM_CPUS, in a job be a multiple of PAR_GROUPS , so each group will have the same number of processors. It is also best that all processors in a job be the same speed.
The maximum number of processors in any group is : m_pe_grp = ( NUM_CPUS + par_groups - 1 ) / par_groups The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is : n_pe_grp_2 = par_groups * m_pe_grp - NUM_CPUS The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is : n_pe_grp_1 = PAR_GROUPS - n_pe_grp_2
DIV_TYPE - X node distribution over PES.
KMIG will divide the x image nodes between processors in a group.
Parameters PATH_VEL, PATH_VZ and PATH_ETA and FCTR_VEL define the migration velocity field file name and scale factor array respectively.
Parameters CONST_ETA, CONST_VZVX, TIM_FAR, TIM_NEAR and OFF_FAR describe the anisotropic component for imaging.
CONST_ETA - Anisotropic coefficient. CONST_VZVX - constant Vz / Vx ratio for depth migration. Not used for time migration and DMO. TIM_NEAR - Near mute time used for the migration velocity field. TIM_FAR - Far mute time used for the migration velocity field. OFF_FAR - Far mute offset used for the migration velocity field.
Anisotropic imaging currently exists only for MIG_TYPE = TIM_MIG, DEP_MIG, and OPT_DIR = FORWARD
KMIG uses the 3D velocity field defined by PATH_VEL for imaging.
For time migration and DMO the input velocity functions are converted to RMS velocities using the VELUTIL_CONVERT utility routine. These functions
For DEPTH migration the input velocity functions are converted to interval velocities using the VELUTIL_CONVERT utility routine.
These functions are linearly interpolated to the entire image grid on a coarse vertical time grid which spans the image space and is sampled at a rate of AP_TIM_INC at setup.
KMIG can include an anisotropic coefficient during time or depth migrations similar to that formerly found in APSM. For anisotropic time migration the RMS velocities are converted to the NMO velocities following the procedure described below. For depth migration the values of the velocity coefficients are not altered.
The VEL_ETA parameter indicates the amount of anisotropy assuming that the medium has transverse anisotropy. KMIG will modify its migration operator to be consistent with the VEL_ETA value specified. VEL_ETA = 0.0 indicates a medium that is isotropic. VEL_ETA = 0.1 is a typical value for a transverse anisotropic medium.
If VEL_ETA > 0.0, then KMIG will made an anisotropic migration velocity adjustment based on the TIM_NEAR, TIM_FAR and OFF_FAR parameters. This adjustment will attempt to image the same output event on different offsets at the same time.
The following is a note from Greg Lazear (02/26/98) explaining the TIM_NEAR, TIM_FAR and OFF_FAR parameters:
The parameters TIM_NEAR and TIM_FAR do not mute the traces. They are a way of telling the program the approximate maximum offset at any time on the trace. This is used in a calculation that approximately decouples the migration velocity from the anisotropy parameter VEL_ETA. Normally, changing VEL_ETA will change the moveout travel time curve to a nonhyperbolic shape, and change the apparent velocity needed to stack the event. I wanted velocity and VEL_ETA to be independent so that one could use a flat dip, isotropic velocity field that would work for a range of VEL_ETA's, rather than have to derive a separate velocity field for every VEL_ETA. To do this, I "pegged" the far offset NMO time to that obtained with VEL_ETA = 0, and internally change the migration velocity field as a function of VEL_ETA such that the far offset NMO time remains constant.
Another way to understand it is as follows. Assume you migrate with VEL_ETA = 0 and use a flat-dip, isotropic velocity field, and that the velocities flatten the migrated events over offset (if you output offsets instead of the migrated section). Now if you change VEL_ETA, and the program used the same velocities internally to migrate, the events after migration would no longer be flat, and you would have to rederive velocities that would flatten for that particular VEL_ETA. To prevent this, the program computes internally what modification to velocities is necessary to maintain flat events after migration with that VEL_ETA, but since the moveout is now not hyperbolic, all offsets cannot be kept flat by a change in velocity. So I chose to keep the far offset at that time on the trace flat, and let the intermediate offsets bow up or down with changing VEL_ETA, hoping that this would keep the stacking velocity from changing much with VEL_ETA. Thus, I needed to know what the last unmuted offset is at each time, and that is what the near and far mute line is used for.
So the way to use these parameters correctly is to set them, and the far-offset parameter so that they specify the offset vs time in the trace that you want the NMO time to remain constant as VEL_ETA changes. This should probably be the far muted offset, or close to it.
KMIG can be used in a velocity analysis mode by entering velocity field scale factors in the FCTR_VEL parameter. KMIG produces a different image for each of the FCTR_VEL values.
For TIME migration and DMO KMIG does this by scaling the velocity field by the different FCTR_VEL values and computing different travel times.
For DEPTH migration KMIG divides the traveltime computed with the input velocity function by the FCTR_VEL values. This has the effect of scaling the entire velocity field by this factor.
It uses each of these new velocity fields to produce a different output image for each velocity field. As many output images are created as the number of elements in the FCTR_VEL array.
This velocity scaling will apply to whatever the imaging velocity field is. For anisotropic migration the original input velocity is modified by VEL_ETA, TIM_NEAR, TIM_FAR and OFF_FAR, It is this modified velocity field that is futher modifed by FCTR_VEL.
Output image traces are labeled in header word 24 with the index number of the FCTR_VEL array corresponding to that image, from 1 to the total number of multipliers, and in header word 63 with the corresponding velocity multiplier. Sort order of output traces from fastest to slowest is: FCTR_VEL value, HDR_Y, HDR_Y and offset. It may be necessary to sort output traces to the desired order.
Note the velocity units will define all distance and time units used in KMIG: e.g. Meters / second or feet / second. Note also this does not include the X and Y units.
Parameter PRINT_INC defines how often KMIG will print an information line. KMIG will print a line of information on CPU and wall clock time and input and image trace locations during imaging, for the first 20 input traces and for every PRINT_INC th input trace thereafter.
Parameter DT_INTERP defines the input time increment after interpolation. input time increment / 4. is normal. KMIG interpolates each input trace in time to DT_INTERP. It then uses a nearest neighbor interpolation scheme when it maps the interpolated input trace to each output trace during imaging.
Decreasing DT_INTERP can introduce some step like noise in individualy mapped input traces. This will usually wash out during summation when many input traces are summed, but I would try to avoid this by increasing DT_INTERP.
Increasing DT_INTERP slightly increases KMIGs CPU and memory usage It may also affect the memory cacheing which, depending upon the computer architecture, can in turn significantly affect CPU time.
DT_INTERP = .001 seems to work well for .004 second sample rate input traces. However you could test it with impulse response tests.
Parameter AP_TIM_INC defines a vertical computational grid spacing for imaging.
KMIG computes the input to output time map and the associated amplitude and aliasing coefficients on a coarse vertical grid sampled every AP_TIM_INC output time or depth units. KMIG then maps the input trace to the output traces by linearly interpolating the above functions from the coarse computation grid to the fine output image grid.
Increasing the value of AP_TIM_INC decreases the CPU time, some times siginificantly. However using larger values has the ffect of smoothing the velocity field and can cause linear aritfacts due to the linear coarse to fine time grid interpolation.
To determine a resonable value for AP_TIM_INC, I recommend conducting a series of impulse response tests with different values of AP_TIM_INC (perhaps 10, 20, ... * TIM_INC ) and looking for linear artifacts. The largest value which still has significant CPU savings (as indicated by the .rpt file) without such artifacts and retaing the desired detail of the velocity variations is best. Shallower events will be more affected by these linear artifacts than deeper data. Hence you can probably use a larger value for AP_TIM_INC in deep water GOM than you can in a region with important shallow structure.
Parameters nt_fos and FOS_PWR define the number of fold of stack counters along an output trace, and the fold of stack amplitude scaling exponent respectively.
KMIG keeps a fold of stack counter for each output trace at nt_fos equaly spaced output time or depth locations. After the migration process and before output the fold of stack counter is linearly interpolated along the output vertical axis to every output sample and the output trace amplitude at that time sample scaled by:
FINAL OUTPUT AMPLITUDE = SUMMED OUTPUT AMPLITUDE * (FOLD OF STACK COUNTER) ** FOS_PWR
A value of nt_fos = 1 uses a single, constant fold of stack counter and correction for the entire output trace. using a value of nt_fos = 0 or FOS_PWR = 0 turns the fold of stack correction off.
Because the migration aperture and fresnel zone generally increase with time, the number of input trace samples summed into any given output trace increases significantly with output time. This can cause imbalance in trace amplitudes with time if the fold of stack correction parameters are not selected carefully.
To determine resonable values for nt_fos and FOS_PWR I recommend conducting a series of tests for a single constant value for nt_fos, such as 11, and several different values of FOS_PWR, such as 0, .5, 1. and look for good amplitude balancing. In 2D each test would image a single input line to the same output line. In 3D each experiment would image an apertures worth swath of input lines to a single output line centered on the input swath.
Parameters ALIAS_LENGTH and DIST_AA define the operator antialiasing filter applied during migration.
ALIAS_LENGTH is the maximum length of the alias filter in interpolated input time samples, 31 is normal. DIST_AA is the average separation of input traces in distance units.
KMIG uses the Claerbout integration method for operator anti-aliasing which images a filtered version of the input trace. As the dip of the summation trajectory through the input data increases, KMIG uses a wider filter yielding a lower frequency input trace. The appropriate filter width is a function of the input trace spacing, the separation between input and output traces, the input and output times, which in turn are functions of the velocity field.
Using a larger value of DIST_AA results in more filtering and lower frequencies in the output image. Using a smaller value of DIST_AA results in less filtering and higher frequencies which may conain some aliased noise. Using DIST_AA = 0. turns off the aliasing completely.
This operator anti-aliasing filter is a centered summation of the interpolated input trace using a triangular summation weight which is 1. at the center of the filter and 0. and both ends. The summation is normalized by the triangular area.
For efficiency KMIG constructs a different copy of the input trace for each possible filter length. The maximum half-length of the filter is ALIAS_LENGTH interpolated input time samples long. (Recall that the input trace is interpolated by a factor of DT_INTERP to a finer time scale to allow nearest neighbor interpolation.)
Using a value of ALIAS_LENGTH that is too small may restrict KMIG to too short a maximum filter length which allows some aliased energy to pass. Using a value which is too large may cause KMIG to spend too much time precomputing the filtered traces. (This CPU time is indicated in the .rpt file.) ALIAS_LENGTH = 30 is usually sufficient, ALIAS_LENGTH = 40 is probably excessive and ALIAS_LENGTH = 20 too small.
Too determine resonable values for ALIAS_LENGTH and DIST_AA I recommend you select a constant value of DIST_AA equal to an average input trace spacing, and conduct a series of impulse response tests with different ALIAS_LENGTH and DIST_AA values using an output trace spacing equal to DIST_AA and look for visual aliasing. If visual aliasing exists you would want to increase either ALIAS_LENGTH, DIST_AA or both.
Increasing DIST_AA from the original value selected multiplies the effective distance between output traces (DIST_AA) prior to calculating the anti-alias operator. Values of DIST_AA range from 0.0 (no anti-aliasing) to 2.0 (double anti-aliasing) times the nominal DIST_AA value.
Note this only accounts for the operator or summation aliasing effects. It does not acount for apparent visual inherent in the choice of output space and time sampling.
Parameters PWR_FILT and PHASE_FILT define the migration frequency filter applied to each input trace prior to imaging. This filter accounts for phase and amplitude affects caused by the Kirchhoff summation process.
PWR_FILT - filter exponetial coeffient, .5, 1. are normal for 2D and 3D. PHASE_FILT - filter phase in degrees, 45, 90 are normal for 2D and 3D.
Before migration the amplitude of each input trace is modified by:
INPUT_NEW(FREQUENCY) = INPUT_OLD(FREQUENCY) * FREQUENCY ** PWR_FILT
And the phase of the input trace is changed by PHASE_FILT.
In theory:
PWR_FILT = .5 and PHASE_FILT = 45. for 2D
and
PWR_FILT = 1. and PHASE_FILT = 90. for 3D
However if you are testing a migration with a single input 3D line to a single output 3D line, PWR_FILT = .5 and PHASE_FILT = 45. for 2D
Using PWR_FILT = 0. accentuates lower frequencies. Using PWR_FILT = 3. accentuates higer frequencies.
Output image definiton
Parameters HDR_X and HDR_Y define the X and Y header words respectively. Input trace X and Y midpoints are gotten from header words HDR_X and HDR_Y respectively.
HDR_X - Header word for X coordinates. HDR_Y - Header word for Y coordinates.
KMIG use the information from the transformation grid to determine the scaling between grid and distance units for both the X and Y directions. These will be referred to as X_SCALE and Y_SCALE respectively.
Parameters OFF_TOT, OFF_LAST, OFF_INIT and OFF_INC define the output image offset grid.
OFF_TOT - Number of output offset samples. OFF_LAST - First output offset sample value, in distance units. OFF_INIT - Last output offset sample value, in distance units. OFF_INC - Output offset sample increment, in distance units.
Parameters X_TOT, X_LAST, X_INIT and X_INC define the output image X grid.
X_TOT - Number of output X samples. X_LAST - Initial output X sample value in X units. X_INIT - Last output X sample value in X units. X_INC - Output X sample increment, in X units.
Parameters Y_TOT, Y_LAST, Y_INIT and Y_INC define the output image Y grid.
Y_TOT - Number of output Y samples. Y_LAST - Initial output Y sample value in Y units. Y_INIT - Last Y sample value in Y units. Y_INC - Output Y sample increment, in Y units.
Parameters TIM_TOT, TIM_LAST, TIM_INIT and TIM_INC define the output image time grid.
TIM_TOT - Number of output time or depth samples. TIM_LAST - Minimum output time or depth sample value in time or depth units. TIM_INIT - Maximum output time or depth sample value in time or depth units. TIM_INC - Output time or depth sample increment, in time or depth units.
Imaging aperture
KMIG images each input trace with an aperture defined by a number of input parameters, all starting with an APR prefix.
Only parameters DIST_AP_X_MAX and DIST_AP_Y_MAX affect DMO. All of the aperture parameters are used for time migration.
Parameters OFF_X_MAX, DIST_AP_X_MAX, X_SORT_WIDTH, DIST_AP_X and TIM_AP_X define the X migration aperture.
OFF_X_MAX - Maximum offset in the X direction in distance units. DIST_AP_X_MAX - Maximum X migration half aperture in X units. X_SORT_WIDTH - Additional X migration half aperture in X units held in memory. DIST_AP_X - X aperture distances linked to TIM_AP_X in X units. TIM_AP_X - X aperture times linked to DIST_AP_X in X units.
Note X_SORT_WIDTH is used only if SORT_ORDER = Y_IS_FAST. Note OFF_X_MAX refers to an offset and has units of distance, all other parameters with an X component to the parameter name are in X units.
Parameters OFF_Y_MAX, DIST_AP_Y_MAX, Y_SORT_WIDTH, DIST_AP_Y and TIM_AP_Y define the Y migration aperture.
OFF_Y_MAX - Maximum offset in the Y direction in distance units. DIST_AP_Y_MAX - Maximum Y migration half aperture in Y units. Y_SORT_WIDTH - Additional Y migration half aperture in Y units held in memory. DIST_AP_Y - Y aperture distances linked to TIM_AP_Y in Y units. TIM_AP_Y - Y aperture times linked to DIST_AP_Y in Y units.
Note Y_SORT_WIDTH is used only if SORT_ORDER = X_IS_FAST. Note OFF_Y_MAX refers to an offset and has units of distance, all other parameters with a Y component to the parameter name are in Y units.
The following description of aperture definition applys for SORT_ORDER=X_IS_FAST. If SORT_ORDER=Y_IS_FAST the rolls of X and Y parameters in defining the aperture memory are reversed.
DIST_AP_X_MAX and DIST_AP_Y_MAX define a rectangular aperture extending +/- DIST_AP_X_MAX X units and +/- DIST_AP_X_MAX Y units from the input trace midpoint. KMIG will not image an input trace beyond those limits regardless of any other input parameter. Other input parameters will further limit the image aperture so KMIG will not normally image a given input trace to every output trace within the defined rectangle. KMIG keeps X_TOT * MIN(Y_INIT,2*(DIST_AP_Y_MAX/Y_INC)+1) image traces in memory. Hence increasing DIST_AP_Y_MAX increases the memory usage. Increasing any of the aperture parameters DIST_AP_X_MAX, DIST_AP_Y_MAX or DIST_AP_X , DIST_AP_Y can significantly increase CPU usage. Decreasing any of the aperture parameters DIST_AP_X_MAX, DIST_AP_Y_MAX or DIST_AP_X , DIST_AP_Y can significantly decrease the image dip. Parameters OFF_X_MAX and OFF_Y_MAX are used to precomupte some tables. They do not limit the migration aperture.
I recommend running impulse response tests with different values and looking for a combination which yields acceptable cost and dip.
For DMO the image aperture is further limited to the output traces whcih fall next to a line connecting the source and receiver.
For time migration the image aperture is further limited to an elliptical volume whose foci are the trace source and receiver positions.
For a zero offset trace I define the major axis of the elliptical volume to be the X direction and the minor axis to be Y direction.
For a non zero offset trace I define the major axis of the elliptical volume to be parallel to the trace offset direction and the minor axis to be perpendicular to the trace offset direction.
Depending upon the actual offset, DIST_AP_X and DIST_AP_Y values the mathematically defined major and minor axis could be reversed but I will stick to the above definition in these notes.
The major axis of the elliptical volume at any output time is:
offset / 2 + DIST_AP_X (output time) * X_SCALE in distance units,
and the minor axis of the elliptical volume at that output time is:
DIST_AP_Y (output time) * Y_SCALE in distance units.
If you are imaging input data with a wide range of azimuths I recommend a series of impulse response tests for various input azimuths. For each test image a single input trace with a given azimuth, perhaps 0, 45 and 90 degress to an output volume. You should see the azimuth of the impulse response rotating to follow that of the input trace. You should select the aperture components to capture the desired dips for all azimuths.
To determine DIST_AP_X(output time) or DIST_AP_Y (output time) I recommend a series of impulse response tests in which the offset of the input trace is varied from near to far. In each test a single input trace with zero azimuth and a given offset, (perhaps near, mid and far) is imaged to a single output X or Y centered on the input trace midpoint with the DIST_AP_X(all times) = DIST_AP_X_MAX and DIST_AP_Y (all times) = DIST_AP_X_MAX for all offsets. Then pick the values of DIST_AP_X (output time) DIST_AP_X (output time) the X and Y images respectively that preserve the desired information and eliminates unwanted artifacts for all the imaged offsets.
Parameters offsetS and OFF_TIM define an offset versus time mute that is applied to the output data during imaging.
OFFSETS - offset-Time mute offsets linked to OFF_TIM in distance OFF_TIM - offset-Time mute times linked to offsetS in time
Increasing the value of OFF_TIM for any given offset will reduce the amount of the image volume that is filled and so will reduce the CPU time. This can also reduce some artifacts caused by non physical mapping form input to output time.
To determine OFF_TIM(output offset) I recommend a series of impulse response tests in which the offset of the input trace is varied from near to far. In each test a single input trace with zero azimuth and a given offset, (perhaps near, mid and far) is imaged to a single output X centered on the input trace midpoint with the OFF_TIM = 0 for all offsets. Then pick the OFF_TIM for each offset that preserves the desired information and eliminates unwanted artifacts.
Parameter DOPPLER is used to mute migration events which are stretched beyond a doppler limit. For time migration this is simply the ratio of input time / output time. An input value of DOPPLER< = 0 disables the doppler muting. Increasing the value of DOPPLER increases the amount of migration stretch allowed before muting occurs. 0 - 3 is normal.
Decreasing the value of DOPPLER may eliminate steep dips.
Increasing the value of DOPPLER may introduce low frequency artifacts.
To determine DOPPLER offset I recommend a series of impulse response tests in which a single input trace is imaged for different values of DOPPLER. In each test a single input trace with zero azimuth and a given offset, is imaged to a single output X centered on the input trace midpoint with some DOPPLER value (perhaps 0,2,4,6). Then pick the DOPPLER value that preserves the desired information and eliminates unwanted artifacts. You may choose to test several different offset values.
Parameter TIM_TAPER defines a summation taper length in time units. Parameter DEP_TAPER defines a summation taper length in depth units.
SOURCE AND RECEIVER DATUMS
For depth migration KMIG computes travel times from the source and receiver surface positions to image points. KMIG gets the source and receiver surface depths from either constant values defined by CONST_SRC_DATUM and CONST_REC_DATUM or from the spatialy varying datum files PATH_SRC_DATUM and PATH_REC_DATUM.
If the source andreceivers have the same datum depths the user should use the PATH_REC_DATUM = PATH_SRC_DATUM and RECEVIER_DATUM=CONST_SRC_DATUM
If PATH_SRC_DATUM is other than NONE, KMIG gets the source datum depths from that file. Other wise KMIG set the source datum depths = to the constant CONST_SRC_DATUM. KMIG acts similarly for the receiver datum.
The first two cards of the datum file describe a uniform cartesion grid on which the datum depths are posted while the later cards define the datum X, Y, depth coordinates.
Card 1 contains the X header word, number of points, origin and increment. Card 2 contains the Y header word, number of points, origin and increment. Card 3-nx_fil*ny_fil+2 contain the X and Y locations and datum depths with 1 value per card in file X, Y order. Note the file X and Y header words must be either the image X and Y header words or the image Y and X header words.
The following is an example of a simple datum file which has 3 X nodes defined by header word 7 starting at 0 and incrementing by 100. and 2 Y nodes defined by header word 8 starting at 0 and incrementing by 200.
7, 3, 0., 100. ! X header, number, origin, increment 8, 2, 0., 200. ! Y header, number, origin, increment 0., 0., -100. ! depth at X = 0., Y = 0. 100., 0., -200. ! depth at X = 100., Y = 0. 200., 0., -300. ! depth at X = 200., Y = 0. 0., 200., 200. ! depth at X = 0., Y = 200. 100., 200., -300. ! depth at X = 100., Y = 200. 200., 200., -400. ! depth at X = 200., Y = 200.
TABLE_TEST usage
If TABLE_TEST=YES, KDMIG and KMIG will test each travel time table between FIRST_TABLE to LAST_TABLE before computing it. If the table does not pass the check process it will be recomputed. If it does pass the check process it will not be recomputed.
Note during the check process KTABLE looks at each tables label section for information on the table location. If this is correct, placed there when the table is first computed, the check process is passed. If it is not correct the check process is failed. This can be due to changing table characteristics such as size, a bad disk or if the table has never been computed.
Note TABLE_COMPUTE must be YES for TABLE_TEST to have any effect.
NOTES FOR CONVERSION PROGRAMMER
Old New Parameter Parameter
Miscellaneous parameters
NREPORT - number of input traces between report files TREPORT - CPU time between report files PARTYPE - type of parrellelism RECOVER - Attempt to recover image files. DISKBUF - use disk or memory buffer ALL_OUT - output all x,y image trace SORT_ORDER - order of input and output data. AZIMUTH - output azimuth for inverse imaging SORT_ORDER - order of input and output data. DISPLAY_INFO - Compute and display memory and disk usage PRINT_MEMORY - Print memory allocation PRINT_DEBUG - Print debug information
NDIM DIMENSION - Migration dimensionality. MIGTYPE MIG_TYPE - Migration type. MIGDIR OPT_DIR - Migration direction, FORWARD and INVERSE ALLOUT ALL_OUT - Output all image locations, ONEGRP ONE_IMAGE - Migrate all input traces as one group. OUTTYPE OPT_OUTPUT - Output parameter type, IMAGE, TIME, AMP, ALIAS ONEOUT - One output stream per PE. PAR_GROUPS - Number of parrallel groups. DIVTYPE DIV_TYPE - X node distribution over PES.
Velocity parameters
MODFILE PATH_VEL - velocity file name VZFILE PATH_VZ - VZ file name ETAFILE PATH_ETA - Eta file name VZVX CONST_VZVX - Constant VZ to VX ratio VETA VEL_ETA - Constant eta value VSCALE FCTR_VEL - migration velocity field scale factor. TIMENEAR TIM_NEAR - Near mute time used for anisotropy. TIMEFAR TIM_FAR - Far mute time used for anisotropy. OFFFAR OFF_FAR - Far mute offset used for anisotropy.
Image grid parameters
NOMIG OFF_TOT - Number of output offset samples. O0OUT OFF_LAST - Minimum output offset sample value. OFF_INIT - Maximum output offset sample value. DOMIG OFF_INC - Output offset sample increment.
XCOORD HDR_X - X header word NKMIG X_TOT - Number of output X samples. X0OUT X_LAST - Minimum output X value X_INIT - Maximum output X value DKMIG X_INC - Output X sample increment DXTAP - X taper length
YCOORD HDR_Y - Y header word NYMIG Y_TOT - Number of output Y samples. Y0OUT Y_LAST - Minimum output Y value Y_INIT - Maximum output Y value DYMIG Y_INC - Output Y sample increment DYADD X_SORT_WIDTH - extra X aperture Y_SORT_WIDTH - extra Y aperture DYTAP - Y taper length
NZMIG TIM_TOT - Number of output time samples. Z0OUT TIM_INIT - Minimum output time sample value in time units. TIM_LAST - Maximum output time sample value in time units. DZMIG TIM_INC - Output time sample increment in time units. DZTAP TIM_TAPER - Summation taper length in time units.
NZMIG DEP_TOT - Number of output depth samples. Z0OUT DEP_INIT - Minimum output depth sample value in depth units DEP_LAST - Maximum output depth sample value in depth units DZMIG DEP_INC - Output depth sample increment in depth units. DZTAP DEP_TAPER - Summation taper length in depth units. ZSCALE DEP_SCALE - vertical scale factor
SP_X_TOT - Number of coarse grid X points SP_X_INIT - First coarse grid X value. SP_X_LAST - Last coarse grid X value. SP_X_INC - coarse grid X value increment
SP_Y_TOT - Number of coarse grid Y points SP_Y_INIT - First coarse grid cross value. SP_Y_LAST - last coarse grid line value. SP_Y_INC - coarse grid Y value increment
Aperture parameters
OKMIG OFF_X_MAX - Maximum X offset X1APR DIST_AP_X_MAX - Maximum X migration half aperture
XDIP DIST_AP_X - X aperture distances TXDIP TIM_AP_X - X aperture times TXDIP DEP_AP_X - X aperture depths
OYMIG OFF_Y_MAX - Maximum Y offset Y1APR DIST_AP_Y_MAX - Maximum Y migration half aperture
YDIP DIST_AP_Y - Y aperture distances TYDIP TIM_AP_X - Y aperture times TYDIP DEP_AP_Y - Y aperture depths
OMUTE OFFSETS - offset-Time mute offsets ZMUTE OFF_TIM - offset-Time mute times ZMUTE OFF_DEP - offset-Depth mute depths
XPOLY X_POLY - X polygon values YPOLY Y_POLY - Y polygon values IPOLY ID_POLY - polygon flag PATH_POLY - polygon file name
Filtering parameters
NPRINT PRINT_INC - Number of input traces between printed lines. NTPAD DT_INTERP - Input time interpolation factor. AP_TIM_INC - Output time interpolation factor. AP_DEP_INC - Output depth interpolation factor. DOPPLER DOPPLER - Doppler stretch mute cofficient.
NZFOS nt_fos - Number of fold of stack counters. AZFOS FOS_PWR - Fold of stack exponent.
NALIAS ALIAS_LENGTH - Maximum length of alias filter in input time RALIAS ALIAS_DISTANCE - Average separation of input traces in distance
FAMP1 - zero migration frequency filter coefficient. FAMP2 - nyquist migration frequency filter coefficient. FPOW PWR_FILT - migration filter exponetial coeffient. PHASE PHASE_FILT - migration filter phase.
Datum parameters
VSVR - ratio source to reciver velocities fields ZSPOS CONST_SRC_DATUM - constant source datum level ZRPOS CONST_REC_DATUM - constant receiver datum level ZSFILE PATH_SRC_DATUM - source datum file ZRFILE PATH_REC_DATUM - receiver datum file ZSHIFT - shift between image and input datums ZSIGN - sign between image and input datums
Travel time table parameters
TIMFILE ROOT_TABLE - Travel time table file name PATH_TABLE - Travel time table file name prefix TIMTYPE TYPE_TABLE_CALC - Travel time table computation method TABLE_IMAGE - Image data TIMSTAT - Travel time table status TABLE_INITIALIZE - Zero travel time table file TABLE_COMPUTE - Compute travel time tables TABLE_CHECK - Check travel time table file TIMORD TABLE_ORDER - Travel time table order on disk TIMSIZE TABLE_SIZE - Maximum travel time table size TABTYPE TABLE_SHAPE - travel time table chape MPARTAB PARM_IN_TABLE - number of travle time table paramters MTABMEM TABLES_IN_MEMORY - number of table to save in memory MTABFFIO - Number of travel time tables in ffio memory NPTAB DISK_PACK - pack travel time tables on disk NPMEM MEMORY_PACK - pack travel time tables in memory
SPHERICAL_SCALE - Spherical to linear table interpolation radius IPOS1 FIRST_TABLE - first table to compute IPOS2 LAST_TABLE - last table to compute IPOS0 NEAREST_TABLE - use nearest table
NZTAB AP_DEP_TOT - Number of depth points in a travel time table Z0TAB AP_DEP_INIT - Top depth value in a travel time table AP_DEP_LAST - Bottom depth value in a travel time table DZTAB AP_DEP_INC - Depth value increment in a travel time table
NXPOS TABLE_X_TOT - Number of tables in the X direction. X0POS TABLE_X_INIT - Minimum table position in the X direction TABLE_X_LAST - Maximum table position in the X direction DXPOS TABLE_X_INC - Table position increment in the X direction DXTAB AP_X_INC - X separation withina travel time table.
NYPOS TABLE_Y_TOT - Number of tables in the Y direction. Y0POS TABLE_Y_INIT - Minimum table position in the Y direction TABLE_Y_LAST - Maximum table position in the Y direction DYPOS TABLE_Y_INC - Table position increment in the Y direction DYTAB AP_Y_INC - Y separation withina travel time table.
Raytracing parameters
RAYFILE ROOT_TAB_QC - ray path file name RAYTYPE OPT_RAY - type of ray selection criteria MRAY RAY_MAX_NUMBER - maximum number of rays KTRAY RAY_INTERPOLATION - Number macro time steps between ray intperp LTRAY RAY_MICRO_RATIO - ratio of macro to micro ray time step length DRRAY TABLE_COMP_INC - table computational spatial increment PZRAY RAY_MAX_ANGLE - maximum ray angle
RAY_TIM_TOT - maximum number of ray time points. RAY_TIM_INIT - Maximum ray time length. T1RAY RAY_TIM_LAST - Maximum ray time length. DTRAY RAY_TIM_INC - Ray time increment NARAY RAY_ANG1_TOT - Number of ray angle 1 values, measured from z A0RAY RAY_ANG1_INIT - Minimum ray angle 1 value, measured from z axis A1RAY RAY_ANG1_LAST - Maximum ray angle 1 value, measured from z axis RAY_ANG1_INC - Ray angle 1 value incemrent, measured from z
NBRAY RAY_ANG2_TOT - Number of ray angle 2 values, measured around z B0RAY RAY_ANG2_INIT - Minimum ray angle 2 value, measured around z B1RAY RAY_ANG2_LAST - Maximum ray angle 2 value, measured around z RAY_ANG2_INC - Ray angle 2 value incemrent, measured around z
CIP parameters
NXCIP - Number of CIP traces in the X direction X0CIP - Origin of of CIP traces in the X direction DXCIP - Increment of of CIP traces in the X direction
NYCIP - Number of CIP traces in the Y direction Y0CIP - Origin of of CIP traces in the Y direction DYCIP - Increment of of CIP traces in the Y direction
NOCIP - Number of CIP traces in the offset direction O0CIP - Origin of of CIP traces in the offset direction DOCIP - Increment of of CIP offsets.
MODIFY - modify file name IOTYPE - travel time table io type
------------------------------------------------------------------------------ ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ ADVICE FOR USERS
KMIG passes out its traces 1 at a time.
